People matter, results count. identified in the table of contents by the AFR symbol AFR 2018 Registration Document Annual Financial Report 1 Capgemini is made up of more than 210,000 women and men in over 40 countries, who work with world-renowned clients to find solutions to their most demanding challenges. As a global leader in consulting, technology services, and digital transformation, with unrivalled sectorial expertise, we enable our clients to design and build tomorrow’s businesses, to make the most of the opportunities offered by technology, and to boost their competitiveness and agility. For more than 50 years, the way we operate, work, and collaborate has been guided by our seven core values: Honesty, Boldness, Trust, Freedom, Team Spirit, Modesty, and Fun. These values have shaped who we are today – a responsible leader determined to have a positive impact on all stakeholders within our ecosystem. CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 The French version of this Registration Document (Document de Référence) was filled with the Autorité des marchés financiers (AMF – the French Financial Market Authority) on April 2, 2019, pursuant to Article 212-13 of its General Regulations. It may be used in connection with a financial transaction if it is accompanied by an Information Memorandum approve by the Autorité des marchés financiers (AMF – the French Financial Market Authority). This document was prepared by the issuer and engages the responsibility of its signatories. . . . . . . 31 1.5.4 Non-financial achievements . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 31 Presentation of the Group and its activities Capgemini group fundamentals 1.1 Capgemini group fundamentals 1.1.1 Over 50 years of history From 1967 to today, the milestones of a world leader Founded in 1967 by Mr. Serge Kampf in Grenoble, the Group has Now led by Mr. Paul Hermelin, its Chairman and Chief Executive developed around principles which continue to guide us today: an Officer, the Capgemini group has over 211,000 employees, including entrepreneurial spirit, followed by a passion for clients, an obsession 100,000 in India, and it operates in over 40 countries. Capgemini with getting the best from people, extremely high performance has had the same goal since 1967: Helping businesses to be more expectations, and a commitment to being ethically irreproachable efficient, innovative and agile through technology. at all times. 1967-1974 | The rise of an entrepreneurial spirit 1967 Mr. Serge Kampf founds Sogeti, an IT services company, in Grenoble. 1970 The visionary Sogeti is the first IT services company in Europe to offer organizational Consulting Services. 1974 The first acquisitions with the purchase of two competitors: CAP (France) and Gemini Computer Systems (USA). 1975-1989 | Expansion 1975 Sogeti becomes Cap Gemini Sogeti, the European leader in IT services, with 2,000 employees. 1976 SESA, the French IT services company specializing in systems integration (which will join the Group in 1987), develops TRANSPAC, the first public European data transmission network. 1978 Cap Gemini Sogeti launches on the US market and creates Cap Gemini Inc. in Washington 1985 Cap Gemini Sogeti is listed on the Paris Stock Market: the share price surges +25% in just 5 days. 1987 Acquisition of SESA, the French IT services company. Cap Gemini Sogeti had already held a 42% stake in the company since 1982. 14 1990-1997 | Pursuing leadership 1990-1992 Cap Gemini Sogeti acquires the UK company Hoskyns, the European leader in managed services. Just two years later, Cap Gemini Sogeti becomes the European leader in its sector following successive acquisitions of the Dutch company Volmac – recognized at the time as the most profitable IT services company in Europe – and Programmator, one of the largest IT services companies in Sweden. 1996 Name change to Cap Gemini – removing the Company’s original name (Sogeti). 1998-2001 | Emergence of a global champion 1998 Multinational contract signed with General Motors to develop new client/server systems in 42 countries. 2000 Cap Gemini acquires the consulting arm of Ernst & Young. The Group opens its first offshore production center in Mumbai, India. Cap Gemini now has over 50,000 employees. 2002 à 2009 | New horizons 2002 Mr. Paul Hermelin, who had worked alongside Mr. Serge Kampf since 1993, becomes Group CEO. The Sogeti name returns with the creation of a subsidiary specializing in local IT services. 2003 The Group signs one of the largest outsourcing contracts in its history with the UK’s Inland Revenue. 2007 The Group closes another key acquisition with Kanbay International. This US IT services company specializing in Financial Services has a significant presence in India (7,000 employees). The Group now has 12,000 employees in India. 2007 also marks Capgemini’s commitment to rugby, by becoming the official sponsor of the World Cup in France. CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 Presentation of the Group and its activities Capgemini group fundamentals Since 2010 | An industry leader 2010 Capgemini, now operating in 30 countries, launches in South America with the acquisition of CPM Braxis, the Brazilian IT services 1 company. The Group now has over 100,000 employees worldwide. 2012 45 years after creating the Group, Mr. Serge Kampf stands down as Capgemini Chairman and passes the torch to Mr. Paul Hermelin, who becomes the Group’s Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. 2015 Capgemini acquires the US company IGATE and significantly reinforces its presence in the US and India. 2016 Mr. Serge Kampf passes away at the age of 81 in Grenoble, where he had created Capgemini 49 years previously. 2017 Capgemini launches its new brand identity on its 50-year anniversary. The Group reinforces the flagship Digital and Cloud businesses with the targeted acquisitions of Itelios, TCube Solutions, Idean and Lyons Consulting Group. 2018 Capgemini creates Capgemini Invent, a new line of global services dedicated to digital innovation, consulting and transformation. This brings together Capgemini Consulting and other recently acquired companies under the same banner: LiquidHub, Fahrenheit 212, Idean, Adaptive Lab, Backelite and June21. Capgemini’s history with rugby reaches a new level, as the Group becomes the Global Innovation Partner of the men’s and women’s HSBC World Rugby Sevens Series. The Cloud and Digital businesses now represent around 45% of the Group’s revenue. 1.1.2 Seven values, the foundation of our culture at the heart of what we do Seven values permeate Capgemini’s corporate fabric, from the time Freedom, which means independence in thought, judgment and of their inception by our founder Serge Kampf. These values inspire deeds, and entrepreneurial spirit, creativity. It also means tolerance, and shape our corporate culture and professional conduct. They respect for others, for different cultures and customs: an essential motivate us as a Group and as individuals. Intangible by nature, quality in an international group. they lie at the heart of all our actions as an ethical and responsible Team spirit, meaning solidarity, friendship, fidelity, generosity, company and are the basis of Capgemini’s reputation. fairness in sharing the benefits of collective work; accepting Honesty signifies loyalty, integrity, uprightness, a complete refusal responsibilities and an instinctive willingness to support common to use any underhanded method to help win business or gain any efforts when the storm is raging. kind of advantage. Neither growth nor profit nor independence 15 Modesty, that is simplicity, the very opposite of affectation, have any real worth unless they are won through complete honesty pretension, pomposity, arrogance and boastfulness. Simplicity does and probity. And everyone in the Group knows that any lack of not imply naivety (“simple does not mean simpleton!”); it is more openness and integrity in our business dealings will be penalized at about being discreet, showing natural modesty, common sense, once. being attentive to others and taking the trouble to be understood Boldness, which implies a flair for entrepreneurship and a desire by them. It is about being frank in work relationships, having a to take considered risks and show commitment (naturally linked to relaxed attitude, having a sense of humor. a firm determination to uphold one’s commitments). This is the Fun means feeling good about being part of the Company or one’s very soul of competitiveness: firmness in making decisions or in team, feeling proud of what one does, feeling a sense of forcing their implementation, an acceptance periodically to challenge accomplishment in the search for better quality and greater efficiency, one’s orientations and the status quo. This boldness also needs to feeling part of a challenging project. be combined with a certain level of prudence and a particular clear-sightedness, without which a bold manager is, in reality, merely These values are reflected in our motto: People matter, results dangerously reckless. count . We believe that our clients’ success does not depend on technology only, but also on the women and men who give that Trust, meaning the willingness to empower both individuals and technology life and who make all the difference. Our approach teams; to have decisions made as close as possible to the point thus enables companies and organizations to respond faster to where they will be put into practice. Trust also means giving priority, market trends, to adapt and to improve their performance. within the Company, to real openness toward other people and the widest possible sharing of ideas and information. June 2018, and its application guidance may be consulted at www.afep.com and www.medef.com. 34 CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 Corporate Governance Governance structure and composition of the Board of Directors 2.1 Governance structure and composition of the Board of Directors 2.1.1 History and governance structure 2 BALANCED GOVERNANCE, TAILORED TO CAPGEMINI’S SPECIFIC REQUIREMENTS History decided not to renew this two-tier governance structure and to reinstate Mr. Serge Kampf in his duties as Chairman and Chief The Capgemini group was founded over 50 years ago in 1967 by Executive Officer and to create at his request a position of general Mr. Serge Kampf, who was still Honorary Chairman and Vice-Chairman manager, which had never really existed within the Group. The first at the time of his death on March 15, 2016. Capgemini was shaped holder of this position was Mr. Geoff Unwin, already considered to by Mr. Serge Kampf’s extraordinary qualities. He was an exceptional be the Group’s number two within the Management Board. entrepreneur and a captain of industry the likes of which are rarely seen. In 1967, he was among the first to understand the role of an At the end of the 1990s, having recovered its independence, IT services company. He had taken the Group to the top of its sector Capgemini benefited fully from the euphoria generated by the when he handed Mr. Paul Hermelin the Executive Management of “internet bubble”, the Year 2000 and the birth of the Euro. The the Group in 2002, followed by the Chair of the Board in 2012. He Group had great ambitions. A major milestone was reached in 2000 built the Group based on principles that still apply today: a spirit of with the acquisition of Ernst & Young Consulting, making Capgemini enterprise, a passion for clients, an obsession to help employees the new global leader in its sector and consolidating its positions in grow, ethical conduct at all times and performance at its best. the United States. However, the Group was hit hard by the 2001 economic crisis triggered by the burst of the internet bubble and The story of this half-century can be split into five major periods: difficulties integrating Ernst & Young Consulting. — period one (1967-1996): 29 years of independence In December 2001, after a difficult year whose disappointing results Sogeti was created in Grenoble in October 1967 as a “traditional” only confirmed the threat of recession hanging over the global limited liability company, managed nearly 30 years by the same economy at that time, the Group had 55,000 employees and reported Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Mr. Serge Kampf, its founder annual revenues of around €7 billion, i.e. per capita revenues of and the uncontested leader of a brilliant team of managers that he approximately €125,000, more than 50% above that of the first formed around him and never ceased to promote. Fully conscious period but merely the reflection of the incorporation in the headcount that the Group – if it were to attain the increasingly ambitious in May 2000 of 16,643 consultants from Ernst & Young. 35 objectives that he set each year – could not restrict much longer its Taking note of the decision made – and confirmed – by Mr. Geoff financial capacities to those of its founding Chairman, Mr. Serge Unwin to retire in the near future, the Board of Directors decided, Kampf finally accepted in January 1996 under friendly pressure at the recommendation of its Chairman, to appoint as his replacement from the two other “main” shareholders (CGIP, a partner since 1988 Mr. Paul Hermelin, who became Group general manager alongside and Daimler Benz, shareholder since 1991): Mr. Serge Kampf, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, on January 1, — to propose to the Combined Shareholders’ Meeting of May 24, 2002. 1996 the merger-absorption within Capgemini of the two — period three (2002-2012): a well-prepared transfer of power holding companies that had until then enabled him to retain majority control; On July 24, 2002, Mr. Serge Kampf took the initiative to recommend to the Board of Directors – which accepted – to split the functions — to participate (personally in the amount of FRF 300 million) in of Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, as recently made possible a share capital increase of FRF 2.1 billion, with the balance by the New Economic Regulations Law (NRE). He considered that subscribed in equal parts (FRF 900 million) by Daimler and CGIP; after creating, expanding, leading and managing the Group for — and finally to transfer the head office from Grenoble to Paris. 35 years, the time had come for him to give more power and visibility to the person he considered the best qualified to succeed In May 1996, at the end of this initial period, the Group had him one day. This two-man team operated efficiently and in harmony 25,000 employees (7,000 in France, nearly 4,000 in the United for 10 years, although, according to Mr. Serge Kampf, this was due States, some 12,000 in the triangle formed by the UK, Benelux and more to the relationship of trust, friendship and mutual respect the Nordic countries and around 2,000 across approximately 10 other between the two individuals than what the NRE says regarding the countries) – a 625-fold increase on its initial headcount! – and respective roles, powers and responsibilities of the Chairman and reported annual revenues of approximately FRF 13 billion (€2 billion), the Chief Executive Officer. i.e. per capita revenues of around FRF 520,000 (€80,000). Despite the heavy storm which battered the Group during the first — period two (1996-2002): a changing shareholding structure four years of this period, the Group invested considerable sums in On May 24, 1996, as announced in January to key Group managers, major restructuring operations, the most obvious outcome of which Mr. Serge Kampf presented his proposals to the Shareholders’ was the reinvigoration of all Group companies: for example, at the CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 Meeting which adopted them with a large majority. PAUL HERMELIN Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Member of the Strategy & CSR Committee BIOGRAPHY – PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE Mr. Paul Hermelin is a graduate of École Polytechnique and École Nationale d’Administration. He spent the first fifteen years of his professional life in the French government, primarily in the Ministry of Finance. He held a number of positions in the Budget Office and on various ministry staffs, including that of Finance Minister Jacques Delors. He was chief of staff to the Minister of Industry and Foreign Trade, from 1991 to 1993. Mr. Paul Hermelin joined the Capgemini group in May 1993, where he was first in charge of coordinating Date of birth: central functions. In May 1996, he was appointed member of the Management Board and Chief Executive April 30, 1952 Officer of Capgemini France. In May 2000, following the merger of Capgemini and Ernst & Young Consulting, he became Chief Operating Officer of the Group and director. On January 1, 2002, he became Chief Executive Nationality: Officer of the Capgemini group, followed by Chairman and Chief Executive Officer on May 24, 2012. He has French been a member of the Strategy & Investment Committee since July 24, 2002 (renamed Strategy & CSR Business address: Committee in March 2019). The Board reserves the right to amend at any time the number and/or make-up of these Committees, as well as the scope of their duties. An extract of the Code of Business Ethics is included in the Charter of the Board of Directors and detailed below: “The Directors (and any other person who attends Board or or foreign companies, and their membership on Board Committee meetings) are required to treat as strictly confidential committees of these companies, as well as any change in matters discussed during Board or Committee meetings and all their appointments or participation in these committees. CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 Corporate Governance Group Management 2.3 Group Management 2.3.1 Group Management Management of the Group Capgemini SE Group Management is led by Mr. Paul Hermelin, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, assisted since January 1, 2018, by two Chief Operating Officers, Messrs. Thierry Delaporte and Aiman Ezzat. Group Management is assisted by two bodies comprising the Group’s key operating and functional managers: Group Executive Board Executive Committee The Group Executive Board prepares the broad strategies The Executive Committee assists Group Management define submitted to the Executive Committee for approval and facilitates broad strategies and make decisions regarding the Group’s the carrying out of the Group's operations. It also takes the operating structure, the choice of priority offerings, production necessary measures with regards to the appointment, setting rules and organization and the methods of implementing human of quantitative objectives and performance appraisal of executives resources management. with a wide range of responsibilities. Four special-purpose committees assist Group Management: f The Group f The Mergers & f The Investment f The Risk Review Board Acquisitions Committee Committee Committee Capgemini SE Group Management is led by Mr. Paul Hermelin, — the Merger & Acquisitions Committee, also chaired by the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, assisted since January 1, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, which examines acquisition 2018, by two Chief Operating Officers, Messrs. Thierry Delaporte and divestment projects in the course of identification, selection, and Aiman Ezzat. Mr. Thierry Delaporte has specific responsibility assessment or negotiation; for steering the offerings, industrial expertise, innovation and the — the Investment Committee, chaired by the Chief Financial Indian platform, while Mr. Aiman Ezzat has specific responsibility Officer, which reviews and provides advice with respect to for steering the operating accounts and the commercial management projects requiring investment, including those involving real 76 of clients. Together, the three of them form the Office of the CEO, estate or investment in technologies; ensuring the coherent management of the Company. — the Risk Committee, chaired by the Chief Financial Officer, Group Management is assisted by two bodies comprising the Group’s which is in charge of the effective implementation of the risk key operating and functional managers: the Group Executive Board identification and risk management system and which leads and the Executive Committee. the associated internal controls. In addition, four special-purpose committees assist Group Management: — the Group Review Board, chaired by the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, which examines the major business proposals in the course of drafting or negotiation, multi-national or multi-business framework agreements entered into with clients or suppliers and major contracts involving guarantees given by the Group; PAUL HERMELIN Chairman and Chief Executive Officer BIOGRAPHY – PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE Mr. Paul Hermelin, born on April 30, 1952, is a graduate of École Polytechnique and École Nationale d’Administration. He spent the first fifteen years of his professional life in the French government, primarily in the Ministry of Finance. He held a number of positions in the Budget Office and on various ministry staffs, including that of Finance Minister Jacques Delors. He was chief of staff to the Minister of Industry and Foreign Trade, from 1991 to 1993. Mr. Paul Hermelin joined the Capgemini group in May 1993, where he was first in charge of coordinating central functions. In May 1996, he was appointed member of the Management Board and Chief Executive CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 Officer of Capgemini France. In May 2000, following the merger of Capgemini and Ernst & Young Consulting, he became Chief Operating Officer of the Group and director. On January 1, 2002, he became Chief Executive Officer of the Capgemini group, followed by Chairman and Chief Executive Officer on May 24, 2012. He has been a member of the Strategy & Investment Committee since July 24, 2002. For more detailed information, please refer to the biography published in Section 2.1.3. Corporate Governance Group Management THIERRY DELAPORTE Chief Operating Officer BIOGRAPHY – PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE Mr. Thierry Delaporte, born on May 28, 1967, is a graduate in Political Sciences from SciencesPo Paris and holds a Masters in Law from the Paris La Sorbonne University. Mr. Thierry Delaporte has been Chief Operating Officer of Capgemini since January 1, 2018. He was Head of 2 Capgemini’s Financial Services Strategic Business Unit from January 1, 2013 to December 31, 2017, as well as overseeing Capgemini’s operations in Latin America from January 2016 to December 31, 2017. He is a member of the Group Executive Board. Date of birth: Mr. Thierry Delaporte has spent most of his career with Capgemini. Corporate Governance Group Management AIMAN EZZAT Chief Operating Officer BIOGRAPHY – PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE Mr. Aiman Ezzat, born on May 22, 1961, holds a MSc (Master of Science) in chemical engineering from École Supérieure de Chimie Physique Électronique de Lyon in France and an MBA from the Anderson School of Management at UCLA. Mr. Aiman Ezzat has been Chief Operating Officer of Capgemini since January 1, 2018. He was Chief Financial Officer from December 2012 to the end of May 2018. He is a member of the Group Executive Board. In March 2017, he was named the “Best European CFO” for the technology and software category in the “2017 Date of birth: All European Executive Team” Institutional Investor’s annual ranking of the region’s top corporate leaders. May 22, 1961 From December 2008 to 2012, he led the Financial Services Global Business Unit (GBU) after serving as Chief Nationality: Operating Officer from November 2007. Mr. Aiman Ezzat has also served as Capgemini’s deputy director of French Strategy from 2005 to 2007. He played a key role in the development of the Booster turnaround plan for the Group’s activities in the United States, as well as in the development of the Group’s offshore strategy. He was Business address: part of the acquisition and integration team of Kanbay, a global IT services firm focused on the Financial Capgemini SE Services industry, acquired by Capgemini in 2006. 11, rue de Tilsitt 75017 Paris Before joining Capgemini, from 2000 to 2004, Mr. Aiman Ezzat served as Managing Director of International Operations at Headstrong, a global business and technology consultancy, where he worked with Financial Number of shares held Services clients in Asia, North America and Europe. at Dec. 31, 2018: 66,940 Mr. Aiman Ezzat was also previously Global Head of the Oil & Gas and Chemicals practice of Gemini Consulting where he spent 10 years (Gemini Consulting was the former brand of the strategic and transformation consulting arm of the Capgemini group, now Capgemini Consulting). The following table summarizes the compensation Code with which Capgemini complies, the compensation of each components subject to shareholder advisory vote pursuant to the Executive Corporate Officers due or awarded in respect of the year Say on Pay policy. then ended must be presented to the Shareholders’ Meeting for a Corporate Governance Compensation of Executive Corporate Officers Compensation components due or awarded in respect of 2018 to Mr. Paul Hermelin, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer and subject to shareholder mandatory vote Amount or accounting value subject to vote Presentation Fixed compensation €1,452,000 (paid in 2018) The gross fixed compensation of €1,452,000 for fiscal year 2018 was approved by the Board of Directors on February 14, 2018 at the recommendation of the Compensation Committee. It represents 2 55% of the total theoretical compensation if objectives are attained and is reviewed at long intervals in accordance with the AFEP-MEDEF Code. This amount is unchanged on 2013 when it was increased by 10% to reflect the change in Mr. Paul Hermelin’s role who became Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at the end of the Combined Shareholders’ Meeting of May 24, 2012, the extension of his responsibilities and the evolution and internationalization of the Group since 2008, when his compensation was last modified. The annualized increase in his theoretical compensation since 2008 and therefore in his fixed compensation is 0.9% per annum. This theoretical compensation falls within the median of CAC 40 executives. Annual variable €1,337,226 During the Board of Directors’ Meeting of March 20, 2019, the Board, based on the audited and compensation (paid in 2019) approved accounts and at the recommendation of the Compensation Committee, assessed the amount of Mr. Paul Hermelin’s variable compensation for fiscal year 2018, of a target amount if objectives are attained of €1,200,000, i.e. 45% of his total theoretical compensation and comprising two equal components, V1 and V2, that may vary between 0% and 200% of the theoretical amount. V1 component: this component is calculated in accordance with quantifiable criteria and the following respective weightings, all relating to the financial results as compared to an ambition decided by the Board: 1) % attainment of the revenue: 30% weighting; 2) % attainment of the operating margin rate: 30% weighting; 3) % attainment of pre-tax net profit: 20% weighting; 4) 2018 organic free cash flow: 20% weighting. These objectives were assessed with respect to the objectives set by the Board of Directors’ Meeting of February 14, 2018. Attainment rates for these four objectives were 101.1%, 97.69%, 102.42% and 110.48% respectively, 91 which taking account of the relative weighting of each objective, gives a weighted attainment rate of 102.22%. The Group’s historical calculation formula accelerates actual performance upwards and downwards such that for 2018: — if the weighted performance of the above four financial indicators is less than or equal to 75%, the V1 component will be nil; — if this weighted performance is greater than or equal to 125%, the V1 component will be capped and equal to twice its theoretical amount. Accordingly, with this formula, a one-point variance in the weighted attainment rate increases or decreases the variable component by 4%. Therefore, application of the formula to the weighted attainment rate of 102.22% in 2018 results in the multiplication of the theoretical variable component by 108.87%, giving an amount of 1,200,000/2*108.87% = €653,226. V2 component: The evaluation and the associated proposal have been prepared on the basis of the work done by the Compensation Committee which reviewed the various personal objectives grouped into two categories: “shared objectives” for 60% and specific objectives for 40% For the shared objectives, the Board defined two sets of indicators evenly spread with an overall 60% weight around i) the effective implementation of the new Group governance and managerial transition with a reinforced collaboration between market units and service lines, positioning the Group on the path to achieve its growth ambition in the Digital and Cloud and its 2020 ambition (out of which 10% are quantifiable) and ii) the operational transformation of the Group with a renewed leadership structure (all based on quantitative indicators). In regard to the first part of shared objectives, through a specific and regular follow up process the Board is evaluating the effective implementation of the Group governance and managerial transition CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 and has evaluated the effective and efficient transformation program by validating the achievement of the 2018 market guidance and an ambitious 2019 budget. For the quantitative part, the Board has validated the fact that the growth of the Digital and Cloud offerings has been published at above 20% and exceeded the growth target set by the Board. On this basis the Board has evaluated the objectives of the first part of shared objectives to be attained at 115%. For the second part of shared objectives related to the successful implementation of the transformation pogram, the Board has validated the new organization in place since July first on one side and has reviewed the expected leadership renewal associated with this new organization noting that 25% of the key business units leaders have changed roles mid year, that from an attractivity standpoint more than 50% of external VP hires in 2018 have been in targeted domains and that the change organization Corporate Governance Compensation of Executive Corporate Officers Amount or accounting value subject to vote Presentation has not generated a leadership disruption with a voluntary attrition of our high performing VPs aligned to our historical trends. On this basis the Board has evaluated the objectives of this second part of shared objectives to be attained at 123%. For the specific personal objectives, the Board defined three sets of objectives. The first specific objective (15% weighting) concerned the impact of M&A on the company growth (quantitative) and the successful post merger integration of acquired companies (qualitative).The disclosed perimeter impact of acquisitions on growth amounted to 2% and a post merger integration report on recently acquired companies has been presented to the Board which on this basis considered that the objectives set for this category have been achieved at 97%. The second specific objective (15% weighting) concerned the deployment of the CSR strategy around 3 pillars (diversity and sustainability being quantitative and digital inclusion being qualitative). Diversity was measured through the % of women in Group Management of our key business units against a target significantly higher than the % of female VP in the VP population. This ambitious target was 96% achieved. On sustainability, the target was to decrease the Green House Gaz emissions per employee by 3% in 2018 and this target has been exceeded. For digital inclusion the strategy including actions already launched, implementation plan and targets have been presented to the December 2018 Board and approved by him. Given these achievements, the Board considered that the objectives set for this category have been achieved at 113%. The third specific objective (10% weighting) concerned the selection of strategic bets in disruptive technologies in order to favour the attainment of the Group growth ambition. A report was presented to the Board and associated bets have been incorporated into the 2019 plans. The Board considered that the objectives set for this category have been realized at 110%. The Board approved a weighted performance of 114% as per the table below: Target Proposal Objective type Computed Qualitative Computed Qualitative 92 New Group governance 10% 20% 11.5% 23.0% Successful transformation program implementation 30% n/a 37.0% n/a M&A impact on growth and post merger success 7.5% 7.5% 7.0% 7.5% Deployment of CSR strategy 10% 5% 12.0% 5.0% Strategic bets on disruptive technologies n/a 10% n/a 11.0% Total 57.5% 42.5% 67.5% 46.5% Target 100% Proposed 114% leading to a V2 calculation of €600,000*114% = €684,000. Accordingly, a variable compensation of €1,337,226 was approved by the Board for 2018, i.e. 92.1% of his fixed compensation for the same year and 111.4% of the theoretical variable compensation. Total fixed and variable compensation for 2018 is therefore €2,789,226, i.e. 105.2% of the theoretical compensation and may be summarized as follows: 2018 Variable compensation calculation for Mr. Paul Hermelin V1: quantitative part based on budgeted financial targets % of Indicators Weight achievement Weighted Total Revenue 30% 101.10% 30.33% Operational Margin % 30% 97.69% 29.31% CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 Net results before tax 20% 102.42% 20.48% Organic free cash flow 20% 110.48% 22.10% Total weighted R/B before flex 102.22% Total weighted post 75/125 flex (4*weighted R/B-3) 108.87% Variable V1 on target 600,000 Computed V1 653,226 Corporate Governance Compensation of Executive Corporate Officers Amount or accounting value subject to vote Presentation V2: qualitative part based on 2018 objectives Categories Weight Weighted total New Group governance 30% 2 Successful transformation program implementation 30% M&A impact on growth and post merger success 15% 114.0% Deployment of CSR strategy 15% Strategic bets on disruptive technologies 10% Variable V2 on target 600,000 Computed V2 684,000 TOTAL 2018 VARIABLE COMPENSATION 1,337,226 As a % of the total variable on target 111.4% As a % of fixed compensation 92.1% The variable compensation due in respect of a given year is calculated based on the audited accounts approved by the Board at the beginning of Y+1 and is paid after the submission of the compensation policy to the shareholders. Deferred variable N/A There is no deferred variable compensation. compensation Multi-year N/A There is no multi-year variable compensation mechanism. variable compensation Exceptional N/A No exceptional compensation was paid. 93 compensation Stock options, Performance 28,000 shares granted subject to performance and presence conditions. performance shares The vesting of performance shares is contingent on the realization of both an external performance shares or any €2,248,954 condition and two internal performance conditions. The external performance conditions accounts other form (IFRS accounting for 35% of the grant and is based on the comparative performance of the Capgemini share over three of long-term value on years against the average performance of a basket of 8 comparable companies in the same business compensation grant date) sector and from at least 5 countries (Accenture/Indra/Atos/Tieto/Sopra Steria/CGI Group/Infosys and Cognizant) the CAC 40 index and the Euro Stoxx 600 index. Accordingly, no shares vest if the relative performance of the Capgemini share is less than 100% of the performance of the basket of comparable companies, while 100% of shares vest only if this relative performance is at 110% or above. If performance is similar to that of the market only 50% of the initial grant vests. The external condition has been strengthened since 2016, as the effective vesting of shares starts from a minimum achievement of 100% of the basket of comparable companies, while it historically started at 90%. The internal performance condition based on organic free cash flow generation over the three-year period from 2018 to 2020 accounts for 50% of the grant. The minimum amount necessary for shares to vest is €3 billion. Above this threshold, shares vest progressively on a straight-line basis, with the maximum grant requiring organic free cash flow of €3.25 billion or more. The internal performance condition on CSR performance indicators measured at the end of 2020 is based for 50% on the percentage of female executives (VPs) joining through promotions and external hiring over the period 2018 to 2020 and should be at 25% to get 100% of the grant with no grant if this % is below 20%. For the remaining 50%, it is based on the reduction of GHG/employee of a minimum 20% vs. the 2015 reference with 100% of the allocation if the reduction reaches 22%. The number of shares that may vest to the Executive Corporate Officer may not exceed 0.001% of the share capital. CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 Authorized by the Combined Shareholders’ Meeting of May 23, 2018 Twenty-third resolution Grant authorized by the Board of Directors on October 3, 2018 Stock No stock options or other items were granted. options = N/A Other items = N/A Corporate Governance Compensation of Executive Corporate Officers Amount or accounting value subject to vote Presentation Attendance Voluntary The Board of Directors took due note of Mr. Paul Hermelin’s decision to waive his right to collect fees waiver attendance fees as a director of Capgemini SE in respect of 2018 (as he has done for the last nine years). Valuation €0 No benefits in kind of benefits in kind Other compensation components Compensation components due or awarded in respect of 2018 that were presented to the Shareholders’ Meeting for vote pursuant to the regulated agreements and commitments procedure Amount subject to vote Presentation Termination N/A No entitlement to termination payments. payments Non-compete N/A No non-compete indemnities. indemnities Supplementary €0 No amount due in respect of the year. pension benefits Mr. Paul Hermelin is a member of the supplementary collective defined benefit pension plan (Article 39) setup in 2006 in Capgemini Service, under the same conditions applicable to other employee members. This plan was reviewed by an external firm which confirmed that it complies with the AFEP-MEDEF recommendations of October 6, 2009, as it complies with the revised AFEP-MEDEF Governance Code issued in June 2013. 94 The plan was closed to new beneficiaries in 2015 and rights of existing members have been frozen as of October 31, 2015. In order to receive benefits under this plan it is necessary to be with the Group at the time of retirement, to have at least 10 years of seniority, to have been a Group Executive Member for at least 5 years and to have a compensation level above 8 PASS (French annual social security ceiling) during 5 years at least. Benefits are based on reference earnings equal to the average of the three best years (fixed and variable part) from among the ten years preceding retirement. In addition, this supplementary pension is subject to three cumulative limits such that the pension amount cannot exceed: — 40% of reference earnings; — 50% of reference earnings, including pensions received under all other pension plans; and — reference earnings are capped at 60 times the French annual social security ceiling. Benefits are proportional to length of service (minimum of 10 years required and a maximum of 30 years), reflecting the required progressive acquisition of entitlement, which remains well below the threshold set by the AFEP-MEDEF Code and the recent legal ceiling of 3% per annum. Entitlement is acquired at a rate of 1.5% per year for the first 10 years of seniority and for subsequent years only at rates of: — 1% up to 20 PASS; — 2% between 20 and 40 PASS; — 3% between 40 and 60 PASS. Therefore, the maximum possible annual entitlement is equal to 1.83% before potential impact of the cumulative limits. Due to the long seniority of our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer (frozen at 23 years in 2015) the value of the annual pension is estimated at a net amount after income tax and CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 employee social contribution of 300k€, corresponding to a gross amount of 901k€ or 34% of his 2018 theoretical compensation. The plan is financed through an external insurance company and as such the required funds to pay the pension support a contribution of 24%. 21 members have benefited from this regime since its launch with 8 presently active as of 31/12/2018. Presented to the Combined Shareholders’ Meeting of April 26, 2007. Fourth resolution in respect of regulated agreements. Annual variable €647,148 During the Board of Directors’ Meeting of March 20, 2019, the Board, based on the audited and compensation (paid in 2019) approved accounts and at the recommendation of the Compensation Committee, assessed the amount of Mr. Thierry Delaporte’s variable compensation for fiscal year 2018, of a target amount if objectives are attained of €590,000, i.e. 40% of his total theoretical compensation and comprising two equal components, V1 and V2, that may vary between 0% and 200% of the theoretical amount. V1 component: this component is calculated in accordance with quantifiable criteria and the following respective weightings, all relating to the financial results as compared to an ambition decided by the Board: 1) % attainment of the revenue: 30% weighting; 2) % attainment of the operating margin rate: 30% weighting; 3) % attainment of pre-tax net profit: 20% weighting; 4) 2018 organic free cash flow: 20% weighting. These objectives were assessed with respect to the objectives set by the Board of Directors’ Meeting of February 14, 2018. Attainment rates for these four objectives were 101.1%, 97.69%, 102.42% and 110.48% respectively, which taking account of the relative weighting of each objective, gives a weighted attainment rate of 102.22%. The Group’s historical calculation formula accelerates actual performance upwards and downwards 96 such that for 2018: — if the weighted performance of the above four financial indicators is less than or equal to 75%, the V1 component will be nil; — if this weighted performance is greater than or equal to 125%, the V1 component will be capped and equal to twice its theoretical amount. Accordingly, with this formula, a one-point variance in the weighted attainment rate increases or decreases the variable component by 4%. Therefore, application of the formula to the weighted attainment rate of 102.22% in 2018 results in the multiplication of the theoretical variable component by 108.87%, giving an amount of 590,000/2*108.87% = €321,173. V2 component: The evaluation and the associated proposal have been prepared on the basis of the work done by the Compensation Committee which reviewed the various personal objectives grouped into two categories: “shared objectives” for 40% and specific objectives for 60% For the shared objectives, the Board defined two sets of indicators evenly spread with an overall 40% weight around i) the effective implementation of the new Group governance and managerial transition with a reinforced collaboration between market units and service lines, positioning the Group on the path to achieve its growth ambition in the Digital and Cloud and its 2020 ambition (out of which 5% are quantifiable) and ii) the operational transformation of the Group with a renewed leadership structure (all based on quantitative indicators). In regard to the first part of shared objectives, through a specific and regular follow up process the Board is evaluating the effective implementation of the Group governance and managerial transition and has evaluated the effective and efficient transformation program by validating the achievement of the 2018 market guidance and an ambitious 2019 budget. For the quantitative part, the Board has validated the fact that the growth of the Digital and Cloud offerings has been published at above 20% and exceeded the growth target set by the Board. On this basis the Board has evaluated the CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 first part of shared objectives to be attained at 117.5%. For the second part of shared objectives related to the successful implementation of the transformation pogram, the Board has validated the new organization in place since July first on one side and has reviewed the expected leadership renewal associated with this new organization noting that 25% of the key business units leaders have changed roles mid year, that from an attractivity standpoint more than 50% of external VP hires in 2018 have been in targeted domains and that the change organization has not generated a leadership disruption with a voluntary attrition of our high performing VPs aligned to our historical trends. On this basis the Board has evaluated the objectives of this second part of shared objectives to be attained at 117.5%. Corporate Governance Compensation of Executive Corporate Officers Amount or accounting value subject to vote Presentation For the specific personal objectives, the Board defined four sets of objectives. The first specific objective (15% weighting) concerned the successful set up of Capgemini Invent and its positive interaction with the rest of the organization. Based on a CEO report explaining the significant growth both in volume and in the number of multi-discipline deals generated by Capgemini 2 Invent which was twice above the set target, the Board considered that the objectives set for this category have been achieved at 133%. The second specific objective (15% weighting) concerned the gross margin evolution versus the 2017 published rate. The 2018 published rate showed an improvement year on year but the set target has not been fully and therefore the Board considered that the objective set for this category has been achieved at 77%. The third specific objective (15% weighting) concerned the success of 4 selected bets within our partners offerings. All 4 bet have reached or exceeded their target and overall vs. the total consolidated bookings target, the performance has been achieved at 112%, percentage retained by the Board for this objective. At last the fourth specific objective (15% weighting) concerned the new strategic positioning of India within the revised organization. The Board considered that the objective set for this category has been realized at 100%. Deferred variable N/A There is no deferred variable compensation. compensation Multi-year €362,880 During the Board of Directors’ Meeting of March 20, 2019, the Board, based on the audited and variable (50% paid approved accounts and at the recommendation of the Compensation Committee, assessed the long 98 compensation in July 19 savings plan of Mr. Thierry Delaporte’s for fiscal year 2018, of a target amount if objectives are and 50% attained of €355,000. This allowance is subject to a performance condition based on the achievement in July 20) of the unflexed weighted performance of the financial indicators of the V1 which for 2018 gives a weighted attainment of 102.22% driving an amount of 102.22%*€355,000= €362,880. — 50% of this amount or €181,440, will be paid in July 2019; — 50% or €181,440 will be paid in July 2020, subject to Mr. Thierry Delaporte being present in the Group as at June 30, 2020. Exceptional N/A No exceptional compensation was paid. compensation Stock options, Performance 16,500 shares granted subject to performance and presence conditions. performance shares The vesting of performance shares is contingent on the realization of both an external performance shares or any €1,325,277 (IFRS condition and two internal performance conditions. The external performance conditions accounts other form accounting for 35% of the grant and is based on the comparative performance of the Capgemini share over three of long-term value on years against the average performance of a basket of 8 comparable companies in the same business compensation grant date) sector and from at least 5 countries (Accenture/Indra/Atos/Tieto/Sopra Steria/CGI Group/Infosys and Cognizant) the CAC 40 index and the Euro Stoxx 600 index. Accordingly, no shares vest if the relative performance of the Capgemini share is less than 100% of the performance of the basket of comparable companies, while 100% of shares vest only if this relative performance is at 110% or above. If performance is similar to that of the market only 50% of the initial grant vests. The external condition has been strengthened since 2016, as the effective vesting of shares starts from a minimum achievement of 100% of the basket of comparable companies, while it historically started at 90%. The internal performance condition based on organic free cash flow generation over the three-year period from 2018 to 2020 accounts for 50% of the grant. The minimum amount necessary for shares to vest is €3 billion. Above this threshold, shares vest progressively on a straight-line basis, with the CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 maximum grant requiring organic free cash flow of €3.25 billion or more. The internal performance condition on CSR performance indicators measured at the end of 2020 is based for 50% on the percentage of female executives (VPs) joining through promotions and external hiring over the period 2018 to 2020 and should be at 25% to get 100% of the grant with no grant if this % is below 20%. For the remaining 50%, it is based on the reduction of GHG/employee of a minimum 20% vs. the 2015 reference with 100% of the allocation if the reduction reaches 22%. The number of shares that may vest to the executive corporate officer may not exceed 0.001% of the share capital. Corporate Governance Compensation Structure de Gouvernance et composition du Conseil of Executive Corporate d’Administration Officers Amount or accounting value subject to vote Presentation Authorized by the Combined Shareholders’ Meeting of May 23, 2018 Twenty-third resolution Stock options Grant authorized by the Board of Directors on October 3, 2018 No stock options or other items were granted. 2 = N/A Other items = N/A Attendance N/A N/A fees Valuation of €2,033 Benefits in kind corresponds to a company car within the existing plan in place in France. benefits in kind Other compensation components Compensation components due or awarded in respect of 2018 that were presented to the Shareholders’ Meeting for vote pursuant to the regulated agreements and commitments procedure Amount subject to vote Presentation Termination €0 No amount due in respect of the year. payments Following the appointement of Mr. Delaporte as Chief Operating Offcier as of January 1, 2018, the Board based on the proposal of the Compensation Committee has authorized, the principle of a severance indemnity which would be due to each Chief Operating Officer in the event of a termination of their corporate office. However, no severance indemnity shall be due if the Chief Operating Officer leaves the company on his own initiative, changes functions within the Group, is entitled to assert in a near future his rights to retirement or in the event of a gross negligence or serious misconduct. 99 In compliance with the recommendations of the revised AFEP-MEDEF Code, the aggregate amount (i) of the severance indemnity effectively paid, (ii) of any indemnity likely to be paid in connection with the termination of an employment agreement, and (iii) of any indemnity likely to be paid in consideration for the non-compete undertaking, may not exceed a maximum amount equal to twice the applicable gross theoretical compensation (fixed plus variable) as at the date of termination of said functions. The granting and the amount of the severance indemnity depend on the percentage of achievement of the weighted performance of the financial indicators due to the Chief Operating Officer in regard to his V1 variable part during each of the last three completed financial years preceding the termination of his functions as Chief Operating Officer, being specified that the last year will count for 40%, while the two previous financial years will count for 30% each. The granting and the amount of the V1 variable part being subject to performance indicators and to the Group’s consolidated results, the severance indemnity is as a result subject to the satisfaction of these same performance conditions. The Board will have to ensure the effective achievement of these performance criteria. Board approval on December 6, 2017 Authorized by the Combined Shareholders’ Meeting of May 23, 2018 Seventh resolution (regulated agreement) Non-compete €0 No amount due in respect of the year. indemnities Upon a proposal of the Compensation Committee, the Board decided that each Chief Operating Officer shall be subject to a non-compete undertaking for a period of twelve months as from the termination of his employment contract following termination of his functions of Chief Operating Officer against an indemnity equal to half of the applicable gross theoretical compensation (fixed plus variable) where all the objectives have been reached as at the date of termination of the functions of Chief Operating Officer. The Board of Directors will be entitled, at its own discretion, to lift this CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 non-compete obligation on departure of the Chief Operating Officer and therefore in such case, not to implement this non-compete indemnity. The following Code with which Capgemini complies, the compensation of Executive table summarizes the compensation components subject to Corporate Officers due or awarded in respect of the year then shareholder advisory vote pursuant to the Say on Pay policy. ended of each Executive Corporate Officer must be presented to Corporate Governance Compensation Structure de Gouvernance et composition du Conseil of Executive Corporate d’Administration Officers Compensation components due or awarded in respect of 2018 to Mr. Aiman Ezzat, Chief Operating Officer and subject to shareholder mandatory vote Amount or accounting value subject to vote Presentation Fixed compensation €936,000 (paid in 2018) The gross fixed compensation of €936,000 for fiscal year 2018 was approved by the Board of Directors on February 14, 2018 at the recommendation of the Compensation Committee. It represents 60% of 2 the total theoretical compensation if objectives are attained and is reviewed at long intervals in accordance with the AFEP-MEDEF Code. This amount was proposed following the nomination as of January 1, 2018 of Mr. Aiman Ezzat as Chief Operating Officer and this proposal has been approved by the shareholders at the May 23, 2018 Combined Shareholders’ Meeting. Annual variable €687,562 During the Board of Directors’ Meeting of March 20, 2019, the Board, based on the audited and compensation (paid in 2019) approved accounts and at the recommendation of the Compensation Committee, assessed the amount of Mr. Aiman Ezzat’s variable compensation for fiscal year 2018, of a target amount if objectives are attained of €624,000, i.e. 40% of his total theoretical compensation and comprising two equal components, V1 and V2, that may vary between 0% and 200% of the theoretical amount. V1 component: this component is calculated in accordance with quantifiable criteria and the following respective weightings, all relating to the financial results as compared to an ambition decided by the Board: 1) % attainment of the revenue: 30% weighting; 2) % attainment of the operating margin rate: 30% weighting; 3) % attainment of pre-tax net profit: 20% weighting; 4) 2018 organic free cash flow: 20% weighting. These objectives were assessed with respect to the objectives set by the Board of Directors’ Meeting of February 14, 2018. Attainment rates for these four objectives were 101.1%, 97.69%, 102.42% and 110.48% respectively, which taking account of the relative weighting of each objective, gives a weighted attainment rate of 102.22%. The Group’s historical calculation formula accelerates actual performance upwards and downwards 101 such that for 2018: — if the weighted performance of the above four financial indicators is less than or equal to 75%, the V1 component will be nil; — if this weighted performance is greater than or equal to 125%, the V1 component will be capped and equal to twice its theoretical amount. Accordingly, with this formula, a one-point variance in the weighted attainment rate increases or decreases the variable component by 4%. Therefore, application of the formula to the weighted attainment rate of 102.22% in 2018 results in the multiplication of the theoretical variable component by 108.87%, giving an amount of 624,000/2*108.87% = €339,682. V2 component: The evaluation and the associated proposal have been prepared on the basis of the work done by the Compensation Committee which reviewed the various personal objectives grouped into two categories: “shared objectives” for 40% and specific objectives for 60%. For the shared objectives, the Board defined two sets of indicators evenly spread with an overall 40% weight around i) the effective implementation of the new Group governance and managerial transition with a reinforced collaboration between market units and service lines, positioning the Group on the path to achieve its growth ambition in the Digital and Cloud and its 2020 ambition (out of which 5% are quantifiable) and ii) the operational transformation of the Group with a renewed leadership structure (all based on quantitative indicators). In regard to the first part of shared objectives, through a specific and regular follow up process the Board is evaluating the effective implementation of the Group governance and managerial transition and has evaluated the effective and efficient transformation program by validating the achievement of the 2018 market guidance and an ambitious 2019 budget. For the quantitative part, the Board has validated the fact that the growth of the Digital and Cloud offerings has been published at above 20% and exceeded the growth target set by the Board. On this basis the Board has evaluated the CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 first part of shared objectives to be attained at 117.5%. For the second part of shared objectives related to the successful implementation of the transformation pogram, the Board has validated the new organization in place since July first on one side and has reviewed the expected leadership renewal associated with this new organization noting that 25% of the key business units leaders have changed roles mid year, that from an attractivity standpoint more than 50% of external VP hires in 2018 have been in targeted domains and that the change organization has not generated a leadership disruption with a voluntary attrition of our high performing VPs aligned to our historical trends. On this basis the Board has evaluated the objectives of this second part of shared objectives to be attained at 117.5%. Corporate Governance Structure Compensation composition of ExecutiveetCorporate de Gouvernance Officers du Conseil d’Administration Amount or accounting value subject to vote Presentation For the specific personal objectives, the Board defined four sets of objectives. The first specific objective (15% weighting) concerned the higher contribution to Group growth of the top 100 accounts. The actual growth of our top 100 accounts has been higher than the Group organic growth but just behind the preset ambitious target which drove the Board to assess the performance for this objective to be achieved at 83%. The second specific objective (15% weighting) concerned the gross margin evolution versus the 2017 published rate. The 2018 published rate showed an improvement year on year but the set target has not been fully met and therefore the Board considered that the objective for this category has been achieved at 77%. The third specific objective (15% weighting) concerned the return to growth year on year during the fourth qurter of 2018 of a selected geography. Thanks to a strong focus the return to growth started already in the third quarter and accelerated in the fourth one to end more than twice the target given year on year. Therefore, the Board considered that the objective set for this category has been realized at 150%. At last the fourth specific objective (15% weighting) concerned the management of the CFO role transition from the former one to the newly appointed one. Based on the evaluation made of this transition process by the CEO and considering the fact that Mr. Ezzat had the CFO position for 6 months before transitioning the role and with feedback from various members, the Board has considered that the objective set for this category has been realized at 120%. The Board approved a weighted performance of 111.5% as per the table below: Target Proposal Objective type Computed Qualitative Computed Qualitative New Group governance 5% 15% 6.0% 17.5% Successful transformation program implementation 20% n/a 23.5% n/a 102 Growth of top 100 accounts 15% n/a 12.5% n/a Gross margin % protection / improvement vs. 2017 15% n/a 11.5% n/a Return to YoY growth in Q4 in a selected geography 15% n/a 22.5% n/a CFO role transition n/a 15% n/a 18.0% Total 70% 30% 76.0% 35.5% Target 100% Proposed 111.5% leading to a V2 calculation of €312,000*111.5% = €347,880. In this context, the Group has implemented a systematic and dynamic risk management process in order to ensure the proper conduct of The general economic context and more precisely restrictions business and the attainment of the various strategic objectives, affecting public bodies in the various countries subject to budgetary structured around four key stages – identification, prioritizing, efforts, may weigh on the Group’s revenues and operating margin. processing and steering. A continued slowdown in the activity of certain economic sectors in which our clients operate would also limit their ability to invest The Group has an up-to-date overview of its key risk exposures and and accordingly impact the results of the Group. has defined a specific risk strategy for each risk considered critical. Conversely, a period of slowdown in one or more key Group markets The different risks are presented by type and decreasing order of could offer opportunities, if financial institutions in the widest 115 criticality: sense decide to increase cost cutting programs by investing in — strategy and market risks; digitizing their key processes. — operational risks; Finally, and more generally, a major crisis impacting the financial — security risks; markets or unfavorable trends in macro-economic indicators could — legal and regulatory risks; potentially restrict the Group‘s ability to attain its objectives and — human resource risks; continue its development. — financial risks; — reputation risks. Failure to adapt services portfolio The Group regularly monitors Brexit developments and the Catalan crisis, so as to take appropriate measures to mitigate these risks based Risk factors on decisions taken by the relevant countries and the European Union. Risk management systems Risk management systems The investment policy authorizes the investment of cash surpluses The majority of Group financing is borne by the parent company in money market mutual funds (FCP and SICAV) satisfying the 121 and, as such, implementation of the finance policy is largely “monetary” classification criteria defined by the French Financial centralized. The Group adopts a prudent finance policy based Markets Authority (AMF) and other types of investment (negotiable primarily on: debt securities, term deposits, capitalization contracts) immediately available or with investment periods, potentially renewable, not — prudent use of debt leveraging, coupled with limited use of exceeding 3 months, issued by companies or financial institutions any clauses that could lead to early repayment of borrowings; with a good credit rating (minimum A2/P2 or equivalent). The Group — the maintenance of an adequate level of liquidity at all times; also applies maximum concentration per counterparty rules. — the active management of financial liability maturities, aimed The Group abides by similar risk quality/minimum rating and at limiting the concentration of borrowing maturities; diversification rules when selecting counterparties for foreign currency and interest rate management hedging contracts. — using diverse sources of financing, allowing the Group to reduce its reliance on certain categories of lenders. Equity risk In this context, the Company undertook a specific review of its liquidity risk and considers it is able to meet future scheduled Risk factors payments (see Note 22 to the consolidated financial statements). For the Group, equity risk would consist of unfavorable movements in the stock market value of listed companies in which the Group Foreign currency risk holds investments. Risk factors However, the Group does not hold any shares for financial investment purposes and does not have any interests in listed companies. Capgemini SE is also exposed to the risk of exchange rate fluctuations in respect of inter-company financing transactions and fees paid to the Group by subsidiaries whose functional currency is not the euro (see Note 23 to the consolidated financial statements). Strategy presentation Firmly grounded on the Group’s 50-years old values, our commitment As explained in Section 1.3.1, our CSR strategy is an integral part of to Social Responsibility has been both a guiding principle and an the Group’s strategy and is based on three pillars: diversity, digital area for continuous improvement and renewal as we grow and inclusion and environmental responsibility. CSR is an essential part consolidate our business in a broad geographical space. of our strategy towards employees. It refers to the societal impacts that the Group’s activities have on society and the actions we take As a provider of consultancy, technology and Digital services, and – depending on the nature of the impacts – to their development Capgemini group’s Corporate Social Responsibility runs across key or reduction. areas where our activity has a clear and direct impact: creating a diverse and inclusive work environment, thus enabling our people Our Human Resources strategy is complementary with our CSR to fully develop professionally and bring the best value to our Strategy and is aligned to the Group’s strategy, and to all safety, clients, reducing our impact on the environment and helping clients law-abiding and compliance requirements. Group Human Resources to reduce their impact, and contributing to the development of the empowers each and all our employees to fulfill their potential and societies in which we operate with our specific capabilities and skills. grow professionally and personally by developing their skills-set and achieve sustainable performance in the most effective manners. Our approach is aligned with and respects all national and Corporate Social Responsibility is an essential part of our People international laws and regulations, such as the principles of the Strategy and refers to the societal impacts the Group’s activities 1948 Universal Declaration of Human Rights (where we refuse the entail and the actions we initiate and – depending on the nature of use of forced and child labor), the fundamental conventions on impacts – to either develop, expand or reduce them. labor standards of the International Labor Organization and the OECD guidelines for multinational enterprises. These principles guide all our national and international commitments on Social Responsibility. CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 Our commitment to Social Responsibility Strategy presentation Digital inclusion Our world is being reshaped rapidly by automation and digital Capgemini – as a leading Technology transformation Company – plays revolution and we are facing a huge digital divide and discontinuity a big role in Automation revolution but also recognizes its that is fundamentally impacting every sphere of our society: access responsibility towards mitigating its negative impacts on society. to health, education, continuous learning, finance, labor market… Capgemini commits to make digital an opportunity through its The Digital transformations have direct effects on People Digital Inclusion program. marginalization like under skilled Employees, repetitive job holders, the elderly, rural areas populations, poverty and low development Strategy levers zones, and adding minority groups such as refugees or people in Championing the digital culture: war zones… — use our network and skillsets and mobilise our employees to All of them are far away from the new world and need focus our work in the community and design positive impacts; counter-exclusion measures. While Automation is destroying some existing jobs, it is also creating many new jobs. — encourage managers to participate in thought leadership in the market. But people lack the necessary skills to fill these new jobs, so there is a growing polarization of labor-market opportunities between high Reducing the digital divide: and low-skill jobs, increased unemployment and under-employment especially among young people and mass scale migration to urban areas. — help marginalised populations to be connected to the “e” world; — train and reskill target disadvantaged populations in digital to 4 gain employment, remain relevant and re-integrate in the new world of work. Environmental sustainability Over the past decade, environmental concerns have climbed up Strategy levers the global agenda, with climate change and its related impacts Our environmental sustainability strategy is about reducing our featuring in the World Economic Forum’s top five Global Risks every own environmental impacts (driven by ambitious science-based year since 2011. As a provider of technology, consulting and digital targets), building business resilience to climate change and supporting transformation services supporting several of the world’s largest our clients with their sustainability challenges. companies, we recognise that we have the opportunity to help our clients respond to to environmental threats such as climate change 129 and natural resource depletion. Methodology Following the transposition in France of the European directive The non-financial information to be disclosed are described as 2014/95/UE of 22 October 2014 with regards to the disclosure of follows: social and environmental information (19 July 2017), Capgemini — the Company’s business model; must release in its 2018 management report its first non-financial — the main non-financial risks related to the Company’s activity information statement. This statement includes the information or the use of its products and services; on how the Company takes into account the social and environmental — the policies implemented to handle those risks (including consequences of its activities, including information on the due diligence procedures if applicable); consequences of its activity on human rights compliance, anti-bribery — the actions implemented during the year and the results of and the fight against tax evasion. these policies, including performance indicators. Through our robust environmental management program own environmental impacts against ambitious targets, building (covered in more detail in 4.1.3.2), we measure, manage and business resilience to climate change and supporting our clients reduce our own carbon emissions, with a particular focus on with their sustainability challenges. energy and travel, our largest emission sources. 2. We build business resilience to climate change, with a robust 4.1.3.1 Climate Change Climate Change Risk Assessment process, which uses scientific research to identify the top climate hazards facing each country Climate change strategy & resilience: including and prioritize developing mitigation strategies where they are CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 minimizing carbon impacts and building resilience needed most. to adapt to climate change. 3. We use this huge data set 2015, reaching our 2020 target two years ahead of schedule. to enable a very granular view of greenhouse gas emissions and to help us pinpoint opportunities to reduce emissions. For Capgemini, Climate Change Results having a single global system managed by one team helps ensure our data is relevant, comprehensive, consistent, and complete, with Carbon Accounting a measurement approach that is aligned with the Greenhouse Gas Protocol Corporate Standard. We are committed to continuously improving the quality of our data collection and analysis and using these insights to inform our Carbon Reduction strategic decisions. Due to the lack of reliable data from the energy supplier, 61% of the office energy data for France for Q1-Q3 2018 has been estimated based on 2018 actual data. This estimated data accounts for approximately 4.2% of total Group energy use, 5.8% of total office energy use and 0.4% of total GHG emissions. Waste Management We have applied the principles of the circular economy in numerous ways, from our innovative e-waste partnership with Nodixia in Managing our waste effectively is important in terms of minimizing France to reuse laptops and mobile phones, to localized initiatives our use of finite natural resources, as well as being a tangible, such as swapping disposable cups with reusable ones or replacing impactful way of demonstrating our environmental commitments paper towels for high-efficiency hand driers. In addition, we increased recycling rates, ‘Rethink Waste’ by encouraging them to consider the steps they with 36% of our waste being diverted from landfill in 2018 compared 148 can take to remove avoidable waste from their working day. We to only 28% in 2015. asked people to post a personal pledge on social media using We remain committed to both minimizing the waste we generate #stopbuyingwaste. Objectives — Energy Consumption Model Services that support clients in their own sustainability programs. The Energy Consumption Model is a highly detailed model for Description understanding the true lifecycle cost of IT estate transformation from an energy and carbon perspective. It takes into account the Around the world, organizations are seeking to become more energy consumption of IT hardware, from servers and networks resource efficient and minimize their environmental impacts. We through to end user devices and embodied carbon during device recognize the greatest positive sustainability impact we can have is through helping our clients meet their sustainability challenges. We have set a new target to help our clients save 10 million tonnes manufacture to understand the net environmental impact of IT estate rationalization, refreshment and transformation. 4 of CO2e by 2030 by leveraging the combined innovation and KPIs Results for 2018 capabilities of the Group. Working with our clients to deliver sustainable services is a real opportunity for Capgemini to We have set a long-term target which is to help our clients save demonstrate leadership in the industry and support the transition 10 million tonnes of CO2e by 2030 by leveraging the combined to a low-carbon economy. innovation and capabilities of the Group. As per past practices, the Group measures completion of anti-corruption training Capgemini first launched its Group Ethics & Compliance program in and awareness by all employees world-wide as a key performance 2009, followed by the Group AntiCorruption Policy and an indicator of anti-corruption awareness. 94% of our employees have anti-corruption training and whistle-blowing system around 2011. followed our corruption e-learning. The adoption of the “Sapin II” law in France has strengthened the framework of the fight against corruption and raised the standard, Capgemini has, for several years, engaged in a regular risk-mapping now making it a legal obligation to adopt an anti-corruption exercise at Group level regarding overall risk assessments, including compliance plan covering 8 pillars: (1) an anti-bribery policy, (2) a the risks associated with laws generally, which includes the mandatory system for reporting policy violations, (3) a regularly identification, prevention and control of corruption risks. In 2018 updated map of corruption risks; (4) mandatory due diligence the Group continued working on a detailed Group-level anti-corruption procedures for clients, first-tier suppliers and intermediaries, (5) risk mapping. accounting controls to detect and prevent corruption, (6) corruption In 2018, Capgemini also revised the English and French versions of risk training for managers and most exposed employees, (7) the Anti-Corruption policy (see Section 4.2.2 for more information disciplinary actions against employees for breaches of the policy on SpeakUp and 2.1.2 for more information on our Conflict of and (8) mandatory internal corruption monitoring and assessment Interest policy). It continuously revisits its corporate legal chart to transformation, operating in more than 40 jurisdictions and competing make sure it is in line with the operational needs; in an ever-changing industry. 4) Capgemini’s approach to tax planning is therefore limited to We are exposed to tax risks because of both our global operations taking advantage of available tax measures and reliefs based and the complexity and occasional absence of clarity of international on an honest and objective analysis and in full compliance with and domestic tax rules. Capgemini is engaged in a collaborative, open and 155 We operate within well established and publicized core values, courteous relationship with the tax authorities in all jurisdictions. which include honesty and trust, as well as a strong internal Code Capgemini is committed to responding within the required of Ethics and we are internationally recognized as doing so.
