The Capgemini tax function is composed of a global into the management of the Group’s tax affairs, as follows: network of tax practitioners located in our main geographies who behave as subject matter experts to promote sensitivity 1) Capgemini does not engage in tax evasion or in any other to tax matters and good governance around tax decisions. practices which would be contrary to the Group’s framework Regular interaction with stakeholders coupled with the promotion of ethics and business values; of the tax function ensures that tax risks are identified in a 2) the Group aims to implement an appropriate and reasonable timely manner and any appropriate mitigating action is tax approach when supporting our business, consistently across undertaken when making business decisions; the Group; 7) Capgemini recognizes that using external tax advisors adds 3) Capgemini does not participate in aggressive tax planning and value, particularly when providing advice regarding new legislation transaction structuring for the purpose of tax avoidance or in and interpretation of case law. All advice provided is reviewed ways that are inconsistent with its organization and its operations. by the tax function to ensure any resultant action is in line with It recognizes income and pays taxes in the countries where the our tax principles. activities are undertaken, reflecting the reality of the value The above-mentioned principles apply consistently across the whole generated by its operations, and is committed to applying arm’s group, in all jurisdictions and to all kinds of taxes due by the group length pricing for our cross border internal transactions. entities. Following the transposition in France of the European directive We define material topic as follows: in line with the Framework 2014/95/UE of 22 October 2014 with regards to the disclosure of published by the IIRC, key topics are economic, social and social and environmental information (19 July 2017), Capgemini environmental issues that have an effect on the organization’s must release in its 2018 management report its first non-financial ability to create value. This is determined by considering information statement. Focus on learning and development indicators For learning and development, the Group has implemented a As of 2017, all learning not tracked in the system is not reported on system accessible to all employees, MyLearning. The system any longer. The reason for this is that tracked hours represent more 158 encompasses the full learning catalog (on site and virtual courses, than 96% of all formal learning in MyLearning, and we aim for a webcasts, videos…). It enables monitoring and tracking of the 100%. Reporting only on system-tracked hours allow us to have training delivered. full visibility down to the individual learning activity and secures an auditable trail. Hours of training tracked by the business units via MyLearning system are calculated on the basis of the predefined duration of each training session (and not on the time effectively spent by employees on the training). 3. Focus on digital inclusion indicators Digital inclusion projects — objectives: An initiative will have to support either of the following objectives to be classified as digital inclusion project Below are criteria for projects falling under digital inclusion: by the Group: — definition: Any initiative aimed at reducing the societal digital – help marginalized populations to be connected to the “e” divide by equipping disadvantaged populations to integrate in world: facilitating disadvantaged or marginalized individuals the new world order shaped by automation and digital revolution with digital means and/or training to use technology to be is a Digital Inclusion project. Capgemini group consolidated results 5.1 Analysis of Capgemini group consolidated results 5.1.1 General comments on the Group’s activity in 2018 The Group delivered a strong performance in 2018, combining a Net profit (Group share) amounted to €730 million for 2018, down strengthened growth profile with a further improvement in its on €820 million for 2017, due to the higher tax expense. Basic operating margin and cash flow generation. This attests to the earnings per share for fiscal year 2018 are €4.37 and diluted earnings success of the transformation launched by the Group in recent per share are €4.25. In 2018, the Group generated revenues of €13,197 million, up 5.4% compared with 2017. Momentum was strong in all sectors – except Telecoms, CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 which declined across Europe – growing between 5% and 10%. Operating margin rose 80 basis points to 13.0% for the year. The Asia-Pacific and Latin American region (7% of Group revenues) reported growth of 6.0% at constant exchange rates to €949 million. AsiaPacific benefited this year from an acceleration in the Manufacturing sector, while Latin America delivered both a return to growth and profitability in 2018. Overall, the region’s operating margin therefore improved significantly, from 10.1% in 2017 to 12.8% this year. This acquisition further expands Capgemini’s Digital services capabilities in Italy; Financial information Consolidated accounts Note 3 Alternative performance measures The alternative performance measures monitored by the Group — normalized earnings per share are calculated by dividing are defined as follows: normalized profit or loss attributable to owners of the Company by the weighted average number of ordinary shares outstanding — organic growth, or like-for-like growth, in revenues is the growth during the period, excluding treasury shares. Normalized net rate calculated at constant Group scope and exchange rates. profit or loss is equal to profit for the period attributable to The Group scope and exchange rates used are those for the owners of the Company corrected for the impact of items published period; recognized in “Other operating income and expense” (see — growth at constant exchange rates in revenues is the growth Note 8 – Other operating income and expense), net of tax rate calculated at exchange rates used for the published period; calculated using the effective tax rate; — operating margin is equal to revenues less operating expenses. — net debt (or net cash and cash equivalents) comprises (i) cash It is calculated before “Other operating income and expense” and cash equivalents, as presented in the Consolidated Statement which include amortization of intangible assets recognized in of Cash Flows (consisting of short-term investments and cash business combinations, the charge resulting from the deferred at bank) less bank overdrafts, (ii) cash management assets recognition of the fair value of shares granted to employees (assets presented separately in the Consolidated Statement of (including social security contributions and employer Financial Position due to their characteristics), less (iii) shortcontributions), and non-recurring revenues and expenses, and long-term borrowings. Account is also taken of the impact notably impairment of goodwill, negative goodwill, capital gains of hedging instruments when these relate to borrowings and or losses on disposals of consolidated companies or businesses, own shares; restructuring costs incurred under a detailed formal plan — organic free cash flow calculated based on items in the approved by the Group’s management, the cost of acquiring Statement of Cash Flows is equal to cash flow from operations and integrating companies acquired by the Group, including less acquisitions of property, plant, equipment and intangible earn-outs comprising conditions of presence, and the effects of curtailments, settlements and transfers of defined benefit pension plans; assets (net of disposals) and adjusted for flows relating to the net interest cost. 5 Note 4 Operating segments Group Management analyzes and measures activity performance: the roll-out of uniform expertise and know-how in all countries and regions. — in the geographic areas where the Group is present; 183 Accordingly, the Group presents segment reporting for the five — in the different businesses (Consulting Services, Technology geographic areas where it is located. and Engineering Services, Application Services, and Other Managed Services). CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 Financial information Consolidated accounts Note 5 Consolidated income statement Income and expenses are presented in the Consolidated Income Profit for the year attributable to owners of the Company is Statement by function. Operating expenses are broken down then obtained by taking into account the following items: into the cost of services rendered (corresponding to costs incurred — net finance costs, including net interest on borrowings for the execution of client projects), selling expenses, and general calculated using the effective interest rate, less income from and administrative expenses. cash, cash equivalents and cash management assets; Note 6 Revenues The method for recognizing revenues and costs depends on the Resources-based contracts 186 nature of the services rendered: Revenue from Resources-based contracts is recognized as the Group earns the right to bill the customer as the amount invoiced Deliverable-based contracts corresponds directly to the value to the customer of the Deliverable-based contracts typically include fixed price projects, performance completed to date. Each performance obligation for example, system integration or design and development of is satisfied over time as the client continuously receives and customized IT systems and related processes. Contract terms consumes the benefits of the services. The Services are priced typically range from 6 months to 2 years. Contract prices might based on the number of hours spent on the contract. The amount be subject to incentives and penalties, based on achievement of to be billed is representative of the value of the service delivered specified performance targets or level of benefits delivered to to the customer and therefore, applying the right-to-bill practical the customer. expedient, revenue is recognized over time based on the hours spent. For deliverable-based contracts, revenue is generally recognized over time, because at least one of the following condition is The related costs on resources-based contracts are expensed as met: (i) the Group’s performance enhances an asset that the incurred. customer controls as the Group performs or (ii) the Group builds an asset that has no alternative use (e.g. it is customer-specific) Services-based contracts and the Group has an enforceable right to payment for Services-based contracts include infrastructure management, performance to date in case of termination by the customer. application management and Business Services activities. Contract The Group applies the “cost-to-cost” method to measure progress terms typically range from 3 to 5 years. Fees are billable on a to completion. The percentage of completion is based on costs monthly basis, based on a fixed-price per work unit consumed, incurred to date relative to the total estimate of cost at completion or based on monthly fixed fees subject to adjustment mechanisms of the contract. Estimates of total contract costs are revised for volume changes or scope changes. Contracts generally provide when new elements arise. Change in estimates of cost at for service-level penalties. completion and related percentage of completion are recorded in the Income Statement as catch-up adjustments in the period Recurring services are generally considered to be one single in which the elements giving rise to the revision are known. performance obligation, comprised of a series of distinct daily units of service satisfied over time. Contract modifications are CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 The related costs on deliverable-based contracts are expensed recorded on a prospective basis. Revenue on services-based as incurred. contracts is recognized as rights to bill arise, except in specific The Group earns contractually the right to bill upon achievement cases where invoicing terms do not reflect the value to the of specified milestones or upon customer acceptance of work customer of services rendered to date relative to the value of performed. The difference between cumulative billings and the remaining services (for example, in case of significant cumulative revenue recognized is reflected in the balance sheet front-loaded or backloaded fees or discounts). Service-level as Contract assets (revenue in excess of billings) or Contract penalties or bonuses, if any, are accrued in full the period when liabilities (billings in excess of revenue). the performance targets are failed or achieved, as appropriate. Initial set-up activities, mainly transition phases, necessary to enable the ongoing services, are not considered to be performance 187 Balance sheet presentation obligations. Any amount received in connection with those activities are deferred and recognized in revenue over the Contract assets are presented separately from trade receivables. contractual service period. When multiple Performance Obligations are identified within a single contract, the Group allocates the total contract price to Contract liabilities represent consideration received or receivable the Performance Obligations based on their relative Standalone in advance of performance. Contract assets and liabilities are Selling Price (“SSP”). In the absence of directly observable prices presented on a net basis for each individual contract. for similar services sold separately to similar customers, SSPs are estimated, based on expected costs plus a margin rate commensurate with the nature and risk of the service. Note 10 Income tax expense The income tax expense is the sum of the current tax expense for a period and any adjustment to the current tax amount in and the deferred tax expense. It is recognized in Income Statement, respect of prior periods. The tax payable (or receivable) is except where it relates to a business combination or items calculated using tax rates that have been enacted or substantively recognized in equity or in income and expense recognized in enacted at the year-end. equity. Deferred taxes Current income taxes Deferred taxes are recognized to take account of temporary The current income tax expense is the estimated amount of tax differences between the carrying amounts of certain assets and payable (or receivable) in respect of the taxable profit (or loss) liabilities and their tax basis. See Note 16 – Deferred tax. Note 13 Goodwill and intangible assets Goodwill When the cost of a business combination is less than the fair value of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed, the negative Goodwill is equal to the excess of the acquisition price (plus, goodwill is recognized immediately in the Income Statement in where applicable, non-controlling interests) over the net amount “Other operating income and expense”. recognized in respect of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed. Where an acquisition confers control with remaining Acquisition-related costs are expensed in the Income Statement non-controlling interests (acquisition of less than 100%), the in “Other operating income and expense” in the year incurred. Group elects either to recognize goodwill on the full amount of Goodwill is not amortized but tested for impairment at least revalued net assets, including the share attributable to annually, or more frequently when events or changes in non-controlling interests (full goodwill method) or on the share circumstances indicate that it may be impaired. in revalued net assets effectively acquired only (partial goodwill method). This choice is made for each individual transaction. Customer relationships Goodwill balances are allocated to the different cash-generating On certain business combinations, where the nature of the units (as defined in Note 15 – Cash-generating units and asset customer portfolio held by the acquired entity and the nature impairment tests) based on the value in use contributed to each of the business performed should enable the acquired entity to unit. continue commercial relations with its customers as a result of When a business combination with non-controlling interests efforts to build customer loyalty, customer relationships are 204 provides for the grant of a put option to these non-controlling valued in intangible assets and amortized over the estimated interests, an operating liability is recognized in the Consolidated term of contracts held in portfolio at the acquisition date. Statement of Financial Position in the amount of the estimated exercise price of the put option granted to non-controlling Licenses and software interests, through a reduction in equity. Changes in this put Computer software and user rights acquired on an unrestricted option resulting from any changes in estimates or the unwinding ownership basis, as well as software and solutions developed of the discount are also recognized through equity. Any additional internally and which have a positive, lasting and quantifiable acquisitions of noncontrolling interests are considered a effect on future results, are capitalized and amortized over three transaction with shareholders and, as such, identifiable assets to five years. are not remeasured and no additional goodwill is recognized. The capitalized costs of software and solutions developed internally are costs that relate directly to their production, i.e. the salary costs of the staff that developed the relevant software. CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 Financial information Consolidated accounts Intangible assets by geographic area December 31, 2017 December 31, 2018 Net carrying Acquisitions Net carrying Acquisitions (en millions d’euros) amount during the period amount during the period North America 329 7 367 4 France 98 38 91 32 United Kingdom and Ireland 83 9 82 12 Rest of Europe 25 5 22 2 Asia-Pacific and Latin America 146 6 135 4 INTANGIBLE ASSETS 681 65 697 54 Note 14 Property, plant and equipment (PP&E) Property, plant and equipment Residual values and estimated useful lives are reviewed at each period end. The carrying amount of property, plant and equipment is recorded in assets in the Consolidated Statement of Financial Position The sale of property, plant and equipment gives rise to disposal and corresponds to the historical cost of these items, less gains and losses corresponding to the difference between the accumulated depreciation and any impairment. No items of selling price and the net carrying amount of the relevant asset. property, plant and equipment have been revalued. Buildings owned by the Group are measured based on the components Finance leases approach. Leases that do not transfer to the Group substantially all the Subsequent expenditure increasing the future economic benefits risks and rewards incidental to ownership are classified as associated with assets (costs of replacing and/or bringing assets operating leases, and give rise to lease payments expensed as into compliance) is capitalized and depreciated over the remaining incurred over the lease term. useful lives of the relevant assets. Ongoing maintenance costs However, when the Group assumes substantially all of the risks are expensed as incurred. and rewards incidental to ownership, the lease is classified as a 206 Depreciation is calculated on a straight-line basis over the finance lease and is recognized as an asset at the lower of the estimated useful lives of the relevant assets. It is calculated fair value of the leased asset and the present value of future based on acquisition cost less any residual value. minimum lease payments. The related obligation is recorded in liabilities within borrowings. The asset is depreciated over the Property, plant and equipment are depreciated over the following period during which it is expected to be used by the Group and estimated useful lives: the obligation is amortized over the lease term. Deferred tax is recognized as appropriate. Note 15 Cash-generating units and asset impairment tests Cash-generating units — fair value is the amount obtainable in an arm’s length transaction and is determined with reference to the price in The cash-generating units identified by the Group represent the a binding agreement or the market price in recent and nine geographic areas detailed below. comparable transactions; Asset impairment tests — value in use is based on the discounted future cash flows to be derived from these cash-generating units. Intangible assets and property, plant and equipment with a definite useful life are tested for impairment when there is an The value in use of each cash-generating unit is measured using indication at the period end that their recoverable amount may the discounted future cash flow method, based on the various be less than their carrying amount. Goodwill and assets with an assumptions in the three-year strategic plan extrapolated over indefinite useful life are tested for impairment at least once a a period of five years, including growth and profitability rates year. considered reasonable. Long-term growth rates and discount rates are determined taking account of the specific characteristics The impairment test consists of assessing the recoverable amount 208 of each of the Group’s geographic areas. Discount rates reflect of each asset or group of assets generating cash flows that are the weighted average cost of capital, calculated notably based separate from the cash flows generated by other assets or groups on market data and a sample of sector companies. When the of assets (cash-generating units or CGU). recoverable amount of a cash-generating unit is less than its The recoverable amount is defined as the higher of the fair value carrying amount, the impairment loss is deducted from goodwill less costs to sell of the cash-generating unit and its value in use: to the extent possible and charged under “Other operating income and expenses”. rate recalculated at the measurement date based on current market parameters. — financial liabilities, including longand short-term borrowings and bank overdrafts, accounts and notes payable and other Financial instruments (assets and liabilities) are derecognized current and non-current liabilities; when the related risks and rewards of ownership have been transferred, and when the Group no longer exercises control — derivative instruments. over the instruments. a) Recognition of financial instruments b) Derivative instruments Financial instruments (assets and liabilities) are initially recognized Derivative instruments mainly comprise forward foreign exchange in the Consolidated Statement of Financial Position at their initial purchase and sale contracts (in the form of tunnels, where fair value. applicable) and interest rate swaps. IFRS 9 provisions regarding the classification and measurement When operating or financial cash flow hedges are eligible for of financial assets are based on the Group’s management model hedge accounting, changes in the fair value of the hedging and the contractual terms of financial assets. Depending on their instruments are recognized firstly in “Income and expense classification in the Consolidated Statement of Financial Position, recognized in equity” and subsequently taken to operating profit financial assets and liabilities are subsequently measured at fair or net financial expense when the hedged item itself impacts value through profit or loss, fair value through other the Income Statement. comprehensive income or amortized cost. All changes in the value of hedging costs (time value of foreign Financial liabilities are classified as measured at amortized cost exchange options and forward element of foreign exchange or at fair value through profit or loss if held for trading. forward contracts) are recognized in a separate component of Amortized cost corresponds to the initial carrying amount (net comprehensive income and released to profit or loss when then of transaction costs), plus interest calculated using the effective the hedged flow is realized. interest rate, less cash outflows (coupon interest payments and Other derivative instruments are measured at fair value, with repayments of principal and redemption premiums where changes in fair value, estimated based on market rates or data applicable). Accrued interest (income and expense) is not recorded provided by bank counterparties, recognized in the Income on the basis of the financial instrument’s nominal interest rate, 212 Statement at the reporting date. but on the basis of its effective interest rate. An expected credit loss is recognized on financial assets measured at amortized c) Fair value measurement cost. Any loss in value is recognized in the Income Statement. Fair value measurement methods for financial and non-financial The fair value of a financial instrument is the amount for which assets and liabilities as defined above are classified according to an asset could be exchanged, or a liability settled, between the following three fair value levels: knowledgeable, willing parties in an arm’s length transaction. — level 1: fair values measured based on quoted prices Financial instruments are recognized at inception and on (unadjusted) observed in active markets for identical assets subsequent dates in accordance with the methods described or liabilities; below. These methods draw on the following interest rate — level 2: fair values measured using inputs other than quoted definitions: prices in active markets, that are observable either directly — the coupon interest rate or coupon, which is the nominal (i.e. as prices) or indirectly (i.e. derived from prices); interest rate on borrowings; — level 3: fair values of assets or liabilities measured using — the effective interest rate, which is the rate that exactly inputs that are not based on observable market data discounts the estimated cash flows through the expected (unobservable inputs). term of the instrument, or, where appropriate, a shorter As far as possible, the Group applies Level 1 measurement period to the net carrying amount of the financial asset or methods. liability at initial recognition. CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 Short-term investments Cash management assets At December 31, 2018, short-term investments mainly consist of Cash management assets consist of capitalization contracts with mutual fund units, negotiable debt securities and term bank deposits, insurance companies which may be cancelled by Capgemini SE at paying interest at standard market rates. any time without penalty, as well as marketable securities held by certain Group companies which do not meet all the monetary UCITS classification criteria defined by ESMA (European Securities and Markets Authority) for money market mutual funds, particularly with regards to the average maturity of the portfolio. These funds may, however, be redeemed at any time without penalty. Financial information Consolidated accounts C) Syndicated credit facility negotiated — maintaining an adequate level of available funds at all times; by Capgemini SE — actively managing borrowing due dates in order to limit the On July 30, 2014, the Group signed with a syndicate of 18 banks a concentration of maturities; €750 million multi-currency credit facility, maturing on July 30, — using diverse sources of financing, allowing the Group to reduce 2019, with two one-year extension options, exercisable (subject to its reliance on certain categories of lenders. the approval of the banks) at the end of the first and second years, respectively, extending the maturity of the new facility by a maximum Net debt/net cash and cash equivalents of two additional years. Following the exercise of the second and credit risk one-year extension option, the maturity of this credit facility was extended to July 27, 2021. Financial assets which could expose the Group to a credit or counterparty risk mainly consist of financial investments: in accordance The initial margin on this credit facility was 0.45% (excluding the with Group policy, cash balances are not invested in equity-linked fee on drawn amounts which varies according to the portion of the products, but in (i) negotiable debt securities (certificates of deposit), facility drawn). This margin may be adjusted upwards or downwards (ii) term deposits, (iii) capitalization contracts or (iv) short-term according to the credit rating of Capgemini SE. The facility is also money market mutual funds, subject to minimum credit rating and subject to a fee on undrawn amounts equal to 35% of the margin. diversification rules. The margin currently applicable is 0.45% and the fee on undrawn amounts is 0.1575%. At December 31, 2018, short-term investments totaled €1,476 million and comprise mainly (i) money market mutual fund units meeting An upgrade or downgrade in Capgemini SE’s credit rating would the criteria defined by ESMA (European Securities and Markets have no impact on the availability of this credit facility. The other Authority) for classification in the “monetary category”; and (ii) main terms and conditions of the credit facility, in particular with negotiable debt securities and term deposits maturing within three respect to certain financial ratios, are detailed in Note 29 – Off-balance months or immediately available, issued by highly rated companies sheet commitments. or financial institutions (minimum rating of A2/P2 or equivalent). This credit facility had not been drawn at December 31, 2018. Consequently, these short-term investments do not expose the Group to any material credit risk. A) Exposure to currency risk and currency risk These hedging transactions are recorded in accordance with cash management policy flow hedge accounting rules. a) Currency risk and hedging operating transactions The Group determines the existence of an economic link between The significant use of offshore production centers located in India, the hedging instrument and the hedged item based on the currency, Poland, China and Latin America, exposes the Group to currency amount and timing of their respective cash flows. risk with respect to some of its production costs. b) Currency risk and hedging financial transactions The Group implements a policy aimed at minimizing and managing The Group is exposed to the risk of exchange rate fluctuations in these currency risks, due in the majority to internal flows with India respect of: in respect of production costs denominated in Indian rupee. The hedging policy and the management of operational currency risk is — inter-company financing transactions, mainly within the parent centralized at parent company level. Currency risk is managed company, these flows generally being hedged (in particular primarily based on periodic reporting by subsidiaries of their exposure using forward purchase and sale foreign exchange contracts); to currency risk over principally the coming 1 to 3 years. On this — fees paid to the parent company by subsidiaries whose functional basis, the parent company acting as an internal bank, grants internal currency is not the euro. Financial information Consolidated accounts 5.2.7 Statutory auditors’ report on the consolidated financial statements This is a translation into English of the Statutory auditors’ report on the consolidated financial statements of the Company issued in French and it is provided solely for the convenience of English speaking users. This Statutory auditors’ report includes information required by European regulation and French law, such as information about the appointment of the Statutory auditors or verification of the information concerning the Group presented in the management report. This report should be read in conjunction with, and construed in accordance with, French law and professional auditing standards applicable in France. For the year ended December 31, 2018 To the Annual General Meeting of Capgemini SE, Opinion In compliance with the engagement entrusted to us by your Annual General Meeting, we have audited the accompanying consolidated financial statements of Capgemini SE for the year ended 31 December 2018. In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements give a true and fair view of the assets and liabilities and of the financial position of the Group as at 31 December 2018 and of the results of its operations for the year then ended in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union. The audit opinion expressed above is consistent with our report to the Audit Committee. Basis for Opinion Audit Framework We conducted our audit in accordance with professional standards applicable in France. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our opinion. Our responsibilities under those standards are further described in the Statutory Auditors’ Responsibilities for the Audit of the Consolidated Financial Statements section of our report. Independence We conducted our audit engagement in compliance with independence rules applicable to us, for the period from 1st January 2018 to the date of our report and specifically we did not provide any prohibited non-audit services referred to in Article 5 (1) of Regulation (EU) 234 No 537/2014 or in the French Code of Ethics (Code de déontologie) for Statutory auditors. Emphasis of Matter Without qualifying our conclusion, we draw your attention to Note 1B “New Standards and interpretations applicable in 2018” to the consolidated financial statements, which describes the impact of the application as of January 1, 2018 of IFRS 15 “Revenue from contracts with customers” and IFRS 9 “Financial Instruments”. Justification of Assessments – Key Audit Matters In accordance with the requirements of Articles L. 823-9 and R. 823-7 of the French Commercial Code (Code de commerce) relating to the justification of our assessments, we inform you of the key audit matters relating to risks of material misstatement that, in our professional judgment, were of most significance in our audit of the consolidated financial statements of the current period, as well as how we addressed those risks. These matters were addressed in the context of our audit of the consolidated financial statements as a whole, and in forming our opinion thereon, and we do not provide a separate opinion on specific items of the consolidated financial statements. CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 Financial information Consolidated accounts Recognition of revenue and costs related to long-term service contracts Risks identified Our audit approach Capgemini is present in the professional IT services market and We gained an understanding of the process related to recognizing notably provides long-term services. various revenue flows. As described in Note 6 to the consolidated financial statements, Our approach took into account the information systems used in the method used to recognize revenue and costs related to long-term recognizing revenue and related costs by testing, with the assistance contracts depends on the nature of the services rendered, as of our IT specialists, the effectiveness of the automatic controls for follows: systems impacting revenue recognition. — revenue from deliverable-based contracts is recognized over Our work notably involved: time by using the “cost-to-cost” method to measure progress — assessing internal control procedures, identifying the most to completion. The percentage of completion is based on costs manual or automatic relevant controls for our audit and testing incurred to date relative to the total estimate of cost at their design and operational efficiency; completion of the contract; — based on a sample of contracts: — revenue from Resources-based contracts is recognized as the Group earns the right to bill the customer as the amount – assessing the performance obligations identified within the invoiced corresponds directly to the value to the customer of context of the contract, the performance completed to date; – assessing the method used to recognize revenue and related costs for each identified performance obligations, — revenue on services-based contracts is recognized as rights to – comparing the accounting data against the operational bill arise, except in specific cases where invoicing terms do not monitoring of projects and assessing the reasonableness of reflect the value to the customer of services rendered to date the estimates used, particularly as regards to measuring costs relative to the value of the remaining services (for example, in case of significant front-loaded or back-loaded fees or discounts); — revenue on multi-deliverable contracts should be recognized to be incurred till the end of the contract; — carrying out analytical audit procedures, and notably analyzing 5 material changes in revenue and margin from one period to applying the appropriate method as specified above, depending another; on the performance obligations identified. — assessing the appropriateness of the information provided in Costs incurred to fulfill the contracts are expensed as incurred with the notes to the consolidated financial statements. the exception of certain initial set-up costs, such as transition and transformation costs that do not represent a separate performance obligation, which are capitalized if they create a resource that the Group will use to perform the promised service. 235 A provision for onerous contract is recorded if the unavoidable costs of fulfilling the contract exceed the related benefits. The amount of revenue and the costs to be recognized for the period, and of any provisions for loss at completion at the closing date, depends upon the Group’s ability to: — identify all the performance obligations in the long-term multi-service contracts and determine their related accounting treatment; — measure the costs incurred for deliverable-based contracts or the total services rendered for resourcesbased and services-based contracts; — estimate the costs to be incurred till the end of the contract. Considering the judgments and estimates made by the management to determine how revenue and related costs should be recognized, notably in the context of the first application of the new revenue standard, IFRS 15, we deemed the recognition of revenue and costs related to long-term service contracts to be a key matter in our audit. Financial information Consolidated accounts Verification of the Information Pertaining to the Group Presented in the Management Report As required by law we have also verified in accordance with professional standards applicable in France the information pertaining to the Group presented in the management report of the Board of Directors. We have no matters to report as to its fair presentation and its consistency with the consolidated financial statements. We attest that the consolidated non-financial statement provided for by article L. 2251021 of the French Commercial Code (Code de commerce) is included in the Management Report, it being specified that, in accordance with the provisions of article L. 82310 of said Code, we have verified neither the fair presentation nor the consistency with the financial statements of the information contained in this statement which has to be subject to a report by an independent third party. Report on Other Legal and Regulatory Requirements Appointment of the Statutory auditors We were appointed as Statutory auditors of Capgemini SE by the Annual General Meeting held on 25 April 2002 for KPMG audit and on 24 May 1996 for PricewaterhouseCoopers audit. As at 31 December 2018, KPMG audit and PricewaterhouseCoopers audit were in the 17th year and 23rd year of total uninterrupted engagement. Responsibilities of Management and Those Charged with Governance for the Consolidated Financial Statements Management is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the consolidated financial statements in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union and for such internal control as management determines is necessary to enable the preparation of consolidated financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error. In preparing the consolidated financial statements, management is responsible for assessing the Company’s ability to continue as a going 5 concern, disclosing, as applicable, matters related to going concern and using the going concern basis of accounting unless it is expected to liquidate the Company or to cease operations. The Audit Committee is responsible for monitoring the financial reporting process and the effectiveness of internal control and risks management systems and where applicable, its internal audit, regarding the accounting and financial reporting procedures. The consolidated financial statements were approved the Board of Directors. 239 Statutory auditors’ Responsibilities for the Audit of the Consolidated Financial Statements Objectives and audit approach Our role is to issue a report on the consolidated financial statements. Our objective is to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements as a whole are free from material misstatement. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with professional standards will always detect a material misstatement when it exists. Misstatements can arise from fraud or error and are considered material if, individually or in the aggregate, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic decisions of users taken on the basis of these consolidated financial statements. As specified in Article L. 823-10-1 of the French Commercial Code (Code de commerce), our statutory audit does not include assurance on the viability of the Company or the quality of management of the affairs of the Company. As part of an audit conducted in accordance with professional standards applicable in France, the statutory auditor exercises professional judgment throughout the audit and furthermore: — identifies and assesses the risks of material misstatement of the consolidated financial statements, whether due to fraud or error, designs and performs audit procedures responsive to those risks, and obtains audit evidence considered to be sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for his opinion. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control; — obtains an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the internal control; — evaluates the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of accounting estimates and related disclosures made by management in the consolidated financial statements; — assesses the appropriateness of management’s use of the going concern basis of accounting and, based on the audit evidence obtained, whether a material uncertainty exists related to events or conditions that may cast significant doubt on the Company’s CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 ability to continue as a going concern. This assessment is based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of his audit report. However, future events or conditions may cause the Company to cease to continue as a going concern. If the statutory auditor concludes that a material uncertainty exists, there is a requirement to draw attention in the audit report to the related disclosures in the consolidated financial statements or, if such disclosures are not provided or inadequate, to modify the opinion expressed therein; Financial information Consolidated accounts — evaluates the overall presentation of the consolidated financial statements and assesses whether these statements represent the underlying transactions and events in a manner that achieves fair presentation; — obtains sufficient appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of the entities or business activities within the Group to express an opinion on the consolidated financial statements. The statutory auditor is responsible for the direction, supervision and performance of the audit of the consolidated financial statements and for the opinion expressed on these consolidated financial statements. Report to the Audit Committee We submit a report to the Audit Committee which includes in particular a description of the scope of the audit and the audit program implemented, as well as the results of our audit. We also report, if any, significant deficiencies in internal control regarding the accounting and financial reporting procedures that we have identified. Our report to the Audit Committee includes the risks of material misstatement that, in our professional judgment, were of most significance in the audit of the consolidated financial statements of the current period and which are therefore the key audit matters that we are required to describe in this report. We also provide the Audit Committee with the declaration provided for in Article 6 of Regulation (EU) N° 537/2014, confirming our independence within the meaning of the rules applicable in France such as they are set in particular by Articles L. 822-10 to L. 822-14 of the French Commercial Code (Code de commerce) and in the French Code of Ethics (Code de déontologie) for Statutory auditors. Where appropriate, we discuss with the Audit Committee the risks that may reasonably be thought to bear on our independence, and the related safeguards. The Statutory auditors Neuilly-sur-Seine, 22 February 2019 Paris-La Défense, 22 February 2019 PricewaterhouseCoopers Audit KPMG Audit Division of KPMG S.A. CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 Financial information Comments on the Capgemini SE financial statements 5.3.3 Appropriation of earnings During its meeting of February 13, 2019, the Board of Directors decided to recommend to the next Ordinary Shareholders’ Meeting, the following appropriation of net profit for the year: Net profit for the year €503,817,574.88 Allocation to the legal reserve €0.00 i.e. a balance of €503,817,574.88 Retained earnings of previous years €5,489,022,394.11 i.e. Distributable earnings at December 31, 2018 of €5,992,839,968.99 This amount will be allocated to: – payment of a dividend of €1.70 per share (1) €284,362,859.00 – retained earnings for the balance €5.708,440,627.99 Giving a total of: €5.992.839.968.99 (1) The total amount of the distribution is calculated based on the number of shares ranking for dividends at December 31, 2018 and could therefore change if this number varies between January 1, 2019 and the ex-dividend date. This dividend of €1.70 on each of the 167,293,730 shares bearing The ex-dividend date will be June 7, 2019 and the dividend will be dividend rights on January 1, 2019, will be eligible for the 40% tax payable from June 5, 2019. If, at the time of payment of the dividend, rebate referred to in Article 158.3.2° of the French Tax Code (Code the number of treasury shares held by the Company has changed général des impôts) for private individuals tax-resident in France compared to that held on December 31, 2018, the fraction of the who opt for taxation at the progressive income tax scale. Where dividend relating to this variation will either increase or reduce this option is not made, the dividend will fall within the application retained earnings. scope of the flat-rate income tax advance payment mechanism introduced by the 2018 Finance Act and will no longer be eligible for this 40% rebate. Pursuant to Article 243 bis of the French Tax Code, it is recalled that the following amounts were paid in respect of the past three fiscal years: 242 Dividend Distributed Dividend distribution (1) income (2) per share (in euros) (in euros) (in euros) Fiscal year 2017 286,422,361.40 284,362,859.00 1.70 Fiscal year 2016 261,229,107.40 261,683,477.50 1.55 Fiscal year 2015 231,221,780.55 228,749,429.70 1.35 (1) Theoretical values calculated based on the number of shares bearing dividend rights on December 31 each year. (2) Amounts effectively paid after adjusting the number of shares bearing dividend rights for any change in the number of treasury shares, the issuance of new shares and/or the cancellation of existing shares between January 1 and the ex-dividend date. In fiscal years 2015 and 2016, these amounts were fully eligible for the 40% tax rebate referred to in Article 158.3.2° of the French Tax Code (Code général des impôts). In fiscal year 2017, the distributions were eligible for this rebate when the beneficiary was tax-resident in France and had opted for taxation at the progressive income tax scale. statements 5.4.3 Notes to the financial statements I – Accounting policies received in advance on certificates of deposit and commercial paper is recognized in accrued income or prepaid income, respectively. The annual financial statements for the year ended December 31, Capitalization contracts subscribed by the Company are also included 2018 are prepared and presented in accordance with Regulations in marketable securities. no. 2014-03, no. 2015-05, no. 2015-06 and no. 2016-07 issued by the French Accounting Standards Authority (Autorité des normes Foreign currency transactions comptables, ANC). They are also prepared in accordance with the principles of prudence and accruals, and assuming that the Company Receivables, payables and cash and cash equivalents denominated is able to continue as a going concern. in foreign currencies are translated into euros at the year-end exchange rate or at the hedging rate. Any differences resulting Items in the financial statements are generally measured using the from the translation of foreign currency receivables and payables historical cost method. The Company’s main accounting policies at these rates are included in the balance sheet under “Unrealized are described below: foreign exchange gains/losses”. A provision for foreign exchange losses is set aside to cover any unrealized losses. Intangible assets Computer software and user rights acquired on an unrestricted Receivables and payables ownership basis, as well as software developed for internal use Receivables are measured at their nominal amount, and a provision which has a positive, lasting and quantifiable effect on future results, for impairment set aside when their net realizable value falls below are capitalized and amortized over a maximum period of three their net carrying amount. Unbilled payables are recognized excluding years. At the year-end, the value of computer software and user VAT. rights is compared to their value in use for the Company. Financial fixed assets The gross value of equity interests and other long-term investments Financial instruments Currency and interest rate positions are taken using financial 5 instruments presenting minimum counterparty risk listed on organized carried in the balance sheet comprises their acquisition cost, including markets or over-the-counter. Gains and losses on financial instruments any transaction fees. A provision for impairment is set aside when used in hedging transactions are recognized to match the gains the value in use falls below the acquisition cost. The value in use is and losses arising on the hedged items. Forward financial instruments, calculated based on either the present value of discounted future and options on own shares, are initially recognized in the balance cash flows adjusted for net debt and deferred tax, where applicable, sheet at acquisition cost and subsequently remeasured to fair value. the Company’s share in net assets, or in certain cases, with reference Where there is indication of impairment, a provision for financial to the market value of comparable transactions. risk is set aside in accordance with the principle of prudence. 247 Treasury shares Centralized foreign currency hedging transactions are recognized in accordance with hedge accounting rules. Unhedged transactions Treasury shares held by Capgemini SE as part of the liquidity are recognized in isolated open positions. Any unrealized losses agreement are recorded on the balance sheet within long-term are provided. In addition the impact of hedging on inter-company investments at the lower of cost and net realizable value. Realizable loans and receivables is spread over the hedge term. value is the average market price for Capgemini SE shares in December. Other treasury shares held for other objectives of the Tax consolidation share buyback program are recorded in listed shares. Any tax savings Marketable securities are shown on the balance sheet at the lower realized by the tax consolidation group, primarily on account of tax of cost and net realizable value. This Statutory auditors’ report includes information required by European regulation and French law, such as information about the appointment of the Statutory auditors or verification of the management report and other documents provided to shareholders. This report should be read in conjunction with, and construed in accordance with, French law and professional auditing standards applicable in France. For the year ended 31 December 2018 To the Annual General Meeting of Capgemini SE, Opinion In compliance with the engagement entrusted to us by your Annual General Meeting, we have audited the accompanying financial statements of Capgemini SE for the year ended 31 December 2018. In our opinion, the financial statements give a true and fair view of the assets and liabilities and of the financial position of the Company as at 31 December 2018 and of the results of its operations for the year then ended in accordance with French accounting principles. The audit opinion expressed above is consistent with our report to the Audit Committee. Basis for Opinion Audit Framework We conducted our audit in accordance with professional standards applicable in France. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our opinion. Our responsibilities under those standards are further described in the Statutory auditors’Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements Section of our report. Independence We conducted our audit engagement in compliance with independence rules applicable to us, for the period from 1st January 2018 to the date of our report and specifically we did not provide any prohibited non-audit services referred to in Article 5 (1) of Regulation (EU) No 537/2014 or in the French Code of Ethics (Code de déontologie) for Statutory auditors. 266 Justification of Assessments – Key Audit Matter In accordance with the requirements of Articles L. 823-9 and R. 823-7 of the French Commercial Code (Code de commerce) relating to the justification of our assessments, we inform you of the key audit matter relating to risks of material misstatement that, in our professional judgment, was of most significance in our audit of the financial statements of the current period, as well as how we addressed this risk. This matter was addressed in the context of our audit of the financial statements as a whole, and in forming our opinion thereon, and we do not provide a separate opinion on specific items of the financial statements. CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 Financial information 2018 financial statements Measurement of investments in subsidiaries in Capgemini SE Risks identified Our audit approach At 31 December 2018, equity investments reported in the balance Our work included: sheet amount to €17,043 million. Equity investments are recognized — gaining an understanding of and assessing the impairment at their acquisition-date cost and may be written down based on testing process implemented by Management; their value in use. — when value in use of equity investments is assessed using the As stated in the Note “Accounting policies – Financial Assets” to discounted cash flow method: the financial statements, a depreciation is accounted for should the value in use of the equity investments is lower than its carrying – assessing that the model used to calculate value in use is amount. Specific verification We have also performed, in accordance with professional standards applicable in France, the specific verifications required by French law. Information provided in the management report and in the other documents with respect to the financial position and the financial statements provided to the shareholders We have no matters to report as to the fair presentation and the consistency with the financial statements of the information given in the Board of Directors’ management report and in the other documents with respect to the financial position and the financial statements provided to the shareholders. We attest that the information relating to payment terms referred to in article D. 441-4 of the French Commercial Code (Code de commerce) is fairly presented and consistent with the financial statements. Report on Corporate Governance We confirm the existence in the Report on Corporate Governance of the information required by Articles L. 225-37-3 and L. 225-37-4 of the French Commercial Code (Code de commerce). Concerning the information given in accordance with the requirements of Article L. 225-37-3 of the French Commercial Code (Code de commerce) relating to remunerations and benefits received by the directors and any other commitments made in their favour, we have CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 verified its consistency with the financial statements, or with the underlying information used to prepare these financial statements and, where applicable, with the information obtained by your company from controlling and controlled companies. Based on this work, we attest the accuracy and fair presentation of this information. Financial information 2018 financial statements Other information In accordance with French law, we have verified that the required information concerning the purchase of investments and controlling interests and the identity of the shareholders and holders of the voting rights has been properly disclosed in the management report. Report on Other Legal and Regulatory Requirements Appointment of the Statutory auditors We were appointed as Statutory auditors of Capgemini SE by the Annual General Meeting held on 25 April 2002 for KPMG audit and on 24 May 1996 for PricewaterhouseCoopers audit. As at 31 December 2018, KPMG audit and PricewaterhouseCoopers audit were in the 17th year and 23rd year of total uninterrupted engagement. Responsibilities of Management and Those Charged with Governance for the Financial Statements Management is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the financial statements in accordance with French accounting principles and for such internal control as management determines is necessary to enable the preparation of financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error. In preparing the financial statements, management is responsible for assessing the Company’s ability to continue as a going concern, disclosing, as applicable, matters related to going concern and using the going concern basis of accounting unless it is expected to liquidate the Company or to cease operations. The Audit Committee is responsible for monitoring the financial reporting process and the effectiveness of internal control and risks management systems and where applicable, its internal audit, regarding the accounting and financial reporting procedures. The financial statements were approved by the Board of Directors. Statutory auditors’ Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements Objectives and audit approach Our role is to issue a report on the financial statements. Our objective is to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements as a whole are free from material misstatement. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with professional standards will always detect a material misstatement when it exists. Misstatements can arise from fraud or error and are considered material if, individually or in the aggregate, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic decisions of users taken on the basis of these financial statements. 268 As specified in Article L. 823-10-1 of the French Commercial Code (Code de commerce), our statutory audit does not include assurance on the viability of the Company or the quality of management of the affairs of the Company. As part of an audit conducted in accordance with professional standards applicable in France, the statutory auditor exercises professional judgment throughout the audit and furthermore: — identifies and assesses the risks of material misstatement of the financial statements, whether due to fraud or error, designs and performs audit procedures responsive to those risks, and obtains audit evidence considered to be sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for his opinion. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control; — obtains an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the internal control; — evaluates the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of accounting estimates and related disclosures made by management in the financial statements; — assesses the appropriateness of management’s use of the going concern basis of accounting and, based on the audit evidence obtained, whether a material uncertainty exists related to events or conditions that may cast significant doubt on the Company’s ability to continue as a going concern. This assessment is based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of his audit report. However, future events or conditions may cause the Company to cease to continue as a going concern. If the statutory auditor concludes that a material uncertainty exists, there is a requirement to draw attention in the audit report to the related disclosures in the financial statements or, if such disclosures are not provided or inadequate, to modify the opinion expressed therein; — evaluates the overall presentation of the financial statements and assesses whether these statements represent the underlying transactions and events in a manner that achieves fair presentation. Report to the Audit Committee We submit a report to the Audit Committee which includes in particular a description of the scope of the audit and the audit program CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 implemented, as well as the results of our audit. We also report, if any, significant deficiencies in internal control regarding the accounting and financial reporting procedures that we have identified. Financial information 2018 financial statements Our report to the Audit Committee includes the risks of material misstatement that, in our professional judgment, were of most significance in the audit of the financial statements of the current period and which are therefore the key audit matters that we are required to describe in this report. We also provide the Audit Committee with the declaration provided for in Article 6 of Regulation (EU) N° 537/2014, confirming our independence within the meaning of the rules applicable in France such as they are set in particular by Articles L. 822-10 to L. 822-14 of the French Commercial Code (Code de commerce) and in the French Code of Ethics (Code de déontologie) for Statutory auditors. Where appropriate, we discuss with the Audit Committee the risks that may reasonably be thought to bear on our independence, and the related safeguards. The Statutory auditors Neuilly-sur-Seine and Paris-La Défense, 21 March 2019 PricewaterhouseCoopers Audit KPMG Audit Division of KPMG S.A. Françoise Garnier Richard Béjot Frédéric Quélin Stéphanie Ortega Partner Partner Partner Partner 5 269 CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 Financial information 2018 financial statements 5.4.6 Statutory auditors’ special report on related party agreements and commitments This is a free translation into English of the Statutory auditors’ special report on related party agreements and commitments issued in French and is provided solely for the convenience of English speaking readers. This report should be read in conjunction with, and construed in accordance with, French law and professional auditing standards applicable in France. Shareholders’ Meeting held to approve the financial statements for the year ended 31 December 2018 In our capacity as Statutory auditors of Capgemini SE, we hereby report to you on related party agreements and commitments. It is our responsibility to report to shareholders, based on the information provided to us, on the main terms and conditions of, as well as the reasons provided for, the agreements and commitments that have been disclosed to us or that we may have identified as part of our engagement, without commenting on their relevance or substance or identifying any undisclosed agreements or commitments. Under the provisions of article R. 225-31 of the French Commercial Code (Code de commerce), it is the responsibility of the shareholders to determine whether the agreements and commitments are appropriate and should be approved. Where applicable, it is also our responsibility to provide shareholders with the information required by article R. 225-31 of the French Commercial Code in relation to the performance during the year of agreements and commitments already approved by the Shareholders’ Meeting. We performed the procedures that we deemed necessary in accordance with professional standards applicable in France to such engagements. These procedures consisted in verifying that the information given to us is consistent with the underlying documents. Agreements and commitments submitted for the approval of the Shareholders’ Meeting We hereby inform you that we have not been advised of any agreement or commitment authorized during the year to be submitted to the approval of the Shareholders’ Meeting pursuant to Article L. 225-38 of the French Commercial Code. Agreements and commitments already approved by the Shareholders’ Meeting Agreements and commitments approved in previous years but not implemented during the year We were informed that the following agreements and commitments, approved by the General Meeting in previous years, remained in force during the year ended 31 December 2018 but not implemented. — Supplementary collective pension plan of Paul Hermelin, Chief Executive Officer 270 Type of agreement: A supplementary collective defined benefit pension plan was set up by the Company for certain senior executives regarded as having made a significant and lasting contribution to the development of the Capgemini group. Paul Hermelin was listed as a beneficiary of this plan by decision of the Shareholders’ Meeting of 26 April 2007. Purpose and terms and conditions: On 13 December 2006, the Board of Directors authorised the establishment of a supplementary collective defined benefit pension plan for certain senior executives, enabling them to receive, at retirement, a maximum supplementary pension of 40% of their benchmark remuneration. The total pension collected by the beneficiary may not exceed 50% of this benchmark remuneration, which is itself limited to 60 times the maximum annual salary limit defined by French Social Security. On 29 July 2015, the Board of Directors decided to freeze Paul Hermelin’s rights under this supplementary pension plan with effect from 31 October 2015, without consideration, thus leading to a change in the rules in the Company’s favour. On 5 December 2018, the Board of Directors noted that the agreement was submitted for review. Paul Hermelin received no compensation under this agreement in 2018. Agreements and commitments authorised during the year Furthermore, we were informed that the following agreements and commitments, already approved by the General Meeting on 23 May 2018 upon Statutory auditors’ special report dated 26 February 2018, were not implemented during the year ended 31 December 2018. — Severance pay for Chief Operating Officers Thierry Delaporte and Aiman Ezzat Type and purpose of agreement: The agreement sets out the severance pay entitlement of Thierry Delaporte and Aiman Ezzat in the event of their departure from their position as Chief Operating Officer. CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 Terms and conditions: The severance pay will depend on the percentage of fulfilment of the financial performance objectives applicable to the Chief Operating Officer in question for the V1 variable portion of his remuneration calculated for each of the three complete financial years preceding the termination of his duties as Chief Operating Officer, based on a weighting of 40% for the financial year immediately preceding the termination and 30% for each of the remaining two years. Since the V1 part of the variable remuneration is subject to performance criteria, the severance pay will be conditional upon the fulfilment of these same criteria. In accordance with the recommendations of the AFEP-MEDEF Code, the Board of Directors set an upper limit on the aggregate amount that may be paid out to the Chief Operating Officer with respect to (i) the final calculated amount of severance pay, (ii) the compensation paid under the collective bargaining agreement in the event of termination of the employment contract, and (iii) any compensation that may be paid under a non-competition agreement. This amount is limited to twice the theoretical annual compensation (fixed plus variable) applicable on the date of termination of service. Financial information 2018 financial statements No severance pay would be paid if the Chief Operating Officer leaves of his own accord, if he changes roles within the Group, if he is able to take retirement at very short notice or if he leaves as a result of serious or gross misconduct. Pursuant to article L. 225-42-1 of the French Commercial Code, these appointments are to be submitted for approval to the Shareholders’ Meeting on 23 May 2018, subject to two conditions precedent, namely (i) the adoption of the compensation policy for the Chief Operating Officers by the Shareholders’ Meeting of 23 May 2018, and (ii) the re-appointment of Thierry Delaporte and Aiman Ezzat as Chief Operating Officers by the Board of Directors at the meeting to be held following the Shareholders’ Meeting of 23 May 2018. The two conditions precedent were lifted on May 23, 2019. On 5 December 2018, the Board of Directors noted that the agreement was submitted for review. — Non-competition obligations concerning Chief Operating Officers Thierry Delaporte and Aiman Ezzat Type of agreement: The agreement provides for a non-competition obligation applicable to Thierry Delaporte and Aiman Ezzat, in exchange for which they may be entitled to a compensation payment. Terms and conditions: Subject to compliance with the non-competition obligation for a period of 12 months as from the date of termination of their employment contract further to the termination of their corporate office, the two Chief Operating Officers may be entitled to a compensation payment equal to half of their maximum theoretical gross compensation (fixed plus variable) applicable on the date of termination of their corporate office. The Board of Directors reserves the right to decide to release the Chief Operating Officers from the noncompetition obligation and thus to waive payment of the non-competition compensation payment. In accordance with the recommendations of the AFEP-MEDEF Code, the Board of Directors set an upper limit on the aggregate amount that may be paid out to the Chief Operating Officer with respect to (i) the final calculated amount of severance pay, (ii) the compensation paid under the collective bargaining agreement in the event of termination of the employment contract, and (iii) any compensation that may be paid under a non-competition agreement. This amount is limited to twice the theoretical annual compensation (fixed plus variable) 5 applicable on the date of termination of service. Pursuant to article L. 225-42-1 of the French Commercial Code, these appointments are to be submitted for approval to the Shareholders’ Meeting on 23 May 2018, subject to two conditions precedent, namely (i) the adoption of the compensation policy for the Chief Operating Officers by the Shareholders’ Meeting of 23 May 2018, and (ii) the re-appointment of Thierry Delaporte and Aiman Ezzat as Chief Operating Officers by the Board of Directors at the meeting to be held following the Shareholders’ Meeting of 23 May 2018. The two conditions precedent were lifted on May 23, 2019. 271 On 5 December 2018, the Board of Directors noted that the agreement was submitted for review. CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 (1) Following the repeal of the so-called “trading” exception due to the enactment into French law of the revised Transparency Directive 2013/50/EU by Order no. 2015-1576 of December 3, 2015, service providers must include in their threshold crossing disclosures certain agreements or financial instruments deemed to have an economic effect similar to the ownership of shares, irrespective of whether they are settled in shares or cash (e.g. forward purchases with physical settlement). CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 (1) For illustrative purposes, based on the total number of shares issued and outstanding at March 1, 2019, 16,729,373 shares. 7 Report of the Board of Directors and draft resolutions to be presented at the Combined Shareholders’ Meeting of May 23, 2019 7.1 Resolutions presented at the ordinary Shareholders’ Meeting 288 7.2 Resolutions presented at the extraordinary Shareholders’ Meeting 295 287 7.3 Supplementary report of the Board of Directors on the issuance of shares under the Capgemini group “ESOP 2018” employee shareholding plan 305 7.4 Statutory auditors’ report 309 CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 Report of the Board of Directors and draft resolutions to be presented at the Combined Shareholders’ Meeting of May 23, 2019 Resolutions presented at the ordinary Shareholders’ Meeting This report presents the proposed resolutions submitted to the Combined Shareholders’ Meeting by the Board of Directors. It consists of this introduction and the overview statements preceding the resolutions. The objective of this report is to draw your attention to the important points in the draft resolutions, in accordance with prevailing laws and regulations and with best Corporate Governance practice recommended for companies listed in Paris. It does not purport to be comprehensive and does not replace a careful reading of the draft resolutions prior to voting. An overview of the financial position, activities and results of the Company and its Group during the last fiscal year and other information required by prevailing law and regulations are also presented in the Management Report on fiscal year 2018 included in the 2018 Registration Document (available at www.capgemini.com), to which you are invited to refer. 7.1 Resolutions presented at the ordinary Shareholders’ Meeting PRESENTATION OF THE 1st AND 2nd RESOLUTIONS APPROVAL OF THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS Overview In these two resolutions, we ask you to approve the Company — the Company financial statements of Capgemini SE showing financial statements and the consolidated financial statements a net profit of €503,817,574.88; of Capgemini for the year ended December 31, 2018 as follows: — the consolidated financial statements of Capgemini showing net profit for the Group of €730 million. Ms. Laura Desmond was Chief Executive Officer of Starcom MediaVest Group’s (SMG) Latin America Group, a global marketing and media services company which is part of Publicis Group from 2000 to 2002. From 2003 to 2007, she was Chief Executive Officer of MediaVest, based in New York. She was Chief Executive Officer of SMG – The Americas from 2007 to 2008, where she managed a network spanning the United States, Canada Date of birth: and Latin America. From 2008 to December 2016, she was the Global Chief Executive Officer of SMG. She was March 5, 1965 the Chief Revenue Officer of Publicis Group from December 2016 to December 2017. CAPGEMINI — REGISTRATION DOCUMENT 2018 Report of the Board of Directors and draft resolutions to be presented at the Combined Shareholders’ Meeting of May 23, 2019 Resolutions presented at the extraordinary Shareholders’ Meeting PRESENTATION OF THE 15th AND 16th RESOLUTIONS EMPLOYEE SAVINGS PLANS Overview As part of the employee incentive policy and in order to align New authorization requested in 2019 employee interests with those of shareholders and also stabilize Shareholders are asked to renew the two authorizations by which the Company’s share capital, the Board of Directors wishes to the Shareholders’ Meeting would delegate to the Board its continue making the Company’s share capital accessible to a power to increase the share capital or issue complex securities large number of employees, in particular through employee granting access to equity securities in favor of the Company’s share ownership plans (“ESOP”). Since 2017, such employee employees. This would allow the set-up of a new employee share share ownership operations may now be offered to Group ownership plan in the next eighteen months. employees on an annual basis, while ultimately aiming to maintain employee share ownership at around 5% to 7% of the Company’s An overall ceiling of €24 million (corresponding to 3 million share capital. shares and representing approximately 1.8% of the share capital at December 31, 2018) is proposed for these two delegations. Use of the authorizations granted in 2018 The 15th resolution is intended to allow the Board to carry out During fiscal year 2018, the Board of Directors used the 24th and share capital increases up to a maximum par value amount of 25th resolutions adopted by the Shareholders’ Meeting of May 23, €24 million reserved for members of employee savings plans of 2018, by launching a fifth employee share ownership plan aimed the Company or the Group. This resolution requires the cancellation at associating employees with the Group’s development and of pre-emptive subscription rights. The delegation would be performance.
